DEBATE.TITLE: LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT IN THE SENATE

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Senate for being late for Question Time. I was detained by a Senate committee dealing with the Commonwealth Bank legislation and then I was detained in a lift.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and it concerns the important question of leadership of the Government. In view of the destabilising effect of the Government's leadership crisis upon its ability to address Australia's real economic and political problems, will the Prime Minister now finally either dismiss or otherwise discipline the Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that I might be asked a question about the economy today. Let me say at the beginning that there are a number of assumptions in Senator Hill's question which I do not agree with. In terms of alleged leadership instability, the Prime Minister has stated on a number of occasions that he will lead the Government into the next election. The speculation and interpretation relating to a speech apparently made by the Treasurer at the weekend is, therefore, somewhat academic.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the Prime Minister will be talking to the Treasurer this afternoon about some of these issues. If the Opposition wants further information, the Treasurer himself has made some public comments-as distinct from the comments supposedly made last Friday night-about this issue today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that the Minister table the paper from which he was quoting.
—That is up to the Minister.
—I decline to table it. It is written in my own fine Italian hand, so it is not a document from which I was quoting. It is just a few clues.

—Is the Minister for Defence aware of reports broadcast on the Seven Network News last Thursday evening which claimed that the Holsworthy Army Base was on a security alert as a result of a potential terrorist activity associated with the Hizbolla Islamic Organisation? Can the Minister explain why several hundred members of the armed forces were engaged in stopping traffic on roads around the Army base, why Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel were carrying side-arms, and why they were wearing flak jackets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Channel 7 has not been doing too well in the ratings lately, but resorting to beat-ups of this sort is hardly likely to lift its ratings. The facts surrounding the Holsworthy exercise are these: last Thursday afternoon members of the Australian Defence Force, along with members of the civilian police, carried out an exercise in traffic control on the roads surrounding the base. Some 380 ADF personnel were involved. The traffic control program was one of an ongoing series of exercises that occur at that base-and, I might add, at many other bases-on a regular basis. One of the roads affected was outside the perimeter of the fence. Local police were fully aware of the exercise and actively participated. The exercise ended early on Friday morning. Some individual members of the ADF were carrying weapons but no ammunition was issued. Flak jackets were worn to help ensure realism.

ANSWER.PARA: Last Thursday afternoon, after the commencement of the exercise, Channel 7, amongst others, was advised that a routine exercise was occurring. It was provided with a detailed oral brief and a press release was issued later in the afternoon. Some 3 1/2 hours after that release, Channel 7 chose to broadcast the claim that a security alert was under way as a result of a rumoured terrorist threat. Channel 7 had asked the duty officer at Holsworthy whether the exercise was linked to the Middle East situation and was specifically told no. Army public relations later telephoned the network to ensure that it was clear on this point.

My office has since been in touch with the Channel 7 journalist who prepared the story in an effort to have a correction broadcast. The station has not done so. The chief of the news staff at Channel 7 in Sydney has also been approached by Army public relations for a correction to be broadcast, again without result. Numerous media inquiries resulted from the Channel 7 broadcast. All responsibly accepted the facts regarding the exercise. The result of the Channel 7 broadcast was to cause needless inconvenience to the ADF and police personnel involved and considerable worry and distress to their relatives and local residents. It does little credit to the Seven Network that it broadcast such a beat-up in the first place, and even less that it has ignored repeated opportunities to air a correction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the statement by the Treasurer on Friday that he had Treasury in his pocket and the Reserve Bank of Australia in his pocket. I ask the Minister: how is it possible for the Reserve Bank, or for that matter the Treasury, to offer independent advice to the Treasurer if he has them in his pocket? Does the Minister consider that the politicisation of the major economic policy advisory bodies implicit in this statement is conducive to objective policy advice?

— The Treasurer allegedly made some remarks on Friday night, which I have not seen. There has been all sorts of speculation about the contents of those remarks in the press and elsewhere. I do not want to comment on remarks which I have not seen, in context or elsewhere.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to reports that some Australian banks are proposing to cut the amount of interest free time allowed for credit card use before payments must be made. Is the Government aware of this plan? What views does the Government have on the matter?

—I thank Senator Maguire for this question; he gave me some notice of it. The Government is, of course, aware of media reports suggesting that some financial institutions were considering removing or reducing the current interest free period on credit cards of up to 55 days. State and Territory consumer credit legislation currently prohibits the charging of separate up-front fees as well as interest on credit card balances. By altering the interest free period, which is not affected by credit legislation, financial institutions could be in a position to reduce their credit card interest rates. Some banks already operate without an interest free period, but at an interest rate several percentage points below those charged on cards that do give up to 55 days free credit. If particular financial institutions do remove the interest free period, their customers could consider transferring their business to another institution still offering an interest free period, if they consider that a card with that feature best serves their needs and interests.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Does the Minister recognise that the term `resource security', as applied to guaranteed access to forests by timber companies, is an oxymoron? Does the Minister recognise that the proposed guarantee of resource security is counter to accepted environmental impact assessment procedures and to proposals for ecologically sustainable development? Does the Minister concur with the view of the New South Wales Minister for Environment, Tim Moore, that the Four Corners program, `Navy Blues', which won the 1990 Sir William McKell award for environmental reporting, exposed serious deficiencies in the environmental impact assessment process? Finally, will the Minister resist proposals for exclusive resource access and instead work to strengthen the environmental impact assessment process?

—When it comes to ecologically sustainable development, we will see over the course of the next 12 months some important developments with those groups that have been set up and which are currently working through a series of problems. I would hope that, if we are going to consider resource security legislation, it would be in that context. But I would remind Senator Coulter that the primary responsibility for resource security, if there is to be such a thing, will lie with the States. In answer to a question from Senator Bell last week, I said that I did not regard resource security necessarily as a problem, provided that there was sufficient room for the reservation of areas needed for conservation. At the end of this argument it is a matter of summing up what we have left for conservation purposes, balanced against anything else. That seems to me to be at the heart of the argument. But I do not believe that there is a primary role for the Commonwealth in the process.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand that the Minister is saying, firstly, that the question of sustainable development is a matter which in this area will be left primarily with the States, and there will not be an overriding imposition by the Commonwealth so that we have a national sustainable development policy; and, secondly, that one can guarantee resource security for, say, a timber company-and that is the context in which it has been touted-in which the timber company removes the forest and that that somehow can be part of a sustainable development philosophy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part of any sustainable development philosophy will be the capacity of the timber industry to cut timber from forests. Quite obviously, the question is going to be: what is a sustainable level for the cutting? So I do not rule out logging in Australia because we are going to try to seek ecologically sustainable development. In fact, if we can arrive at a definition of what that is in respect of forests, it may mean less logging in some areas than is carried out now. So it certainly does not have to mean more. But at no stage did we ever suggest that the word `sustainable' meant that no logging was ever possible, so I cannot answer the honourable senator that it was.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the sustainable development work that is being done, there is a responsibility for the Commonwealth to develop a national approach. That is what we are doing with industry, and it is to be hoped that we can take the States with us as well. That is our responsibility. I was merely referring to the fact that, when it comes to access to a forest, on most occasions that will be decided solely by the State government and not by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth will have only a very limited role in that decision, on very limited grounds, and that has been the problem over the last few years. I do not believe that anything I have said undermines there being a national responsibility for a proper, ecologically sustainable development program, but much of its implementation must in the end reside with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I preface my question by referring to the apparent debacle in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) negotiations in Europe. Following the suspension of the GATT Uruguay Round of trade talks last week, can the Minister inform the Senate what the impact on Australia will be and what the Australian Government will do in future to assist Australian industry in the pursuit of its interests in the post-Uruguay Round trading environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Loosely raises a number of large issues in his question. Nonetheless, I will try to address the broad issues that are raised. The first and most important point to make is that, while it is true that the Brussels ministerial meeting last week failed to conclude the Uruguay Round, which it was intended to do, there will nonetheless be efforts made over coming weeks to recapture the progress which has been made across the board as a whole and to restart those talks in the new year. The Director-General of the GATT, Arthur Dunkel, will over the coming weeks be talking to the major participants in the round to see when and how the negotiations can resume. Australia will be encouraging him in that effort because the successful outcome of the Uruguay Round must remain the most important trade policy objective on Australia's national agenda.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to remind ourselves what is at stake here. Quite apart from the particular question of agriculture, which is so centrally important to Australia and on which the round broke down, the round has held out the prospect that the GATT could be brought up to date with the realities of the international trading system in the 1990s and be able to deal with new issues such as the growing importance of trade in services and intellectual property. It also has to do with the failure of the GATT system to deal with the increasing resort by government to protectionism in the 1980s. A failed round, accordingly, would throw away the possibility of making GATT a more relevant and contemporary institution. It would also unquestionably unleash the potential for inward looking solutions to international trading developments and growing pressure for the powerful trading countries and trading blocs to pursue unilateral solutions to their bilateral trade relations and frictions.

The point has been made many times-and it needs to be made again-that Australia, as a medium sized trading power, needs a functioning multilateral trading system to prevent our legitimate trading interests being subverted by protectionist forces. Australia would suffer both from the lost potential for the future of the GATT itself and from any fallout from the international trade wars which could emerge from a failed Uruguay Round environment. That is why attempts to enhance the multilateral trading system remain critical for countries such as Australia and must have priority over other options which inevitably get ventilated at times such as this when the GATT system is clearly under severe pressure.

The European Community (EC) should be-and no doubt will be-concerned about the international odium which it will carry and deserve for the breakdown so far of this round. The inability of the political leaders of the EC to see beyond the narrow interests of their own farming lobbies to the interests of other sectors of their economies, not to mention the international trading system as a whole, should now be a stinging indictment which should create the environment, hopefully, for a major reassessment of the approach which the EC has taken to the negotiations.

Finally, one of the clear messages which emerged from last week's meeting was that the Cairns Group and the United States remained rock solid in their resolve to keep agriculture on the table and not to accept a minimalist outcome. The Cairns Group has ensured, much to the amazement and chagrin of the EC, Japan and others, that no round of trade talks can ignore the legitimate trading interests of a large number of efficient exporters, many of whom are developing countries. In that respect a great deal of the credit for the outcome lies with Australia in its role as Cairns Group convener and with my colleague Dr Blewett, who has carried on the extremely fine tradition set initially by his predecessors John Dawkins and Michael Duffy. The failure of the round owes nothing to the performance, which has been extraordinarily energetic and is acknowledged to be highly professional, of Australia's key Ministers and official negotiators.

Despite all the disappointments that last week represented, the Government will remain committed to the successful prosecution of the round in the coming weeks. We can only hope that that objective is shared by our major trading partners, who do need to bring a new sense of commitment to the round in the post-Brussels period.

— Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to complaints by Mr Reith, the Opposition Treasury spokesman, about the current industrial relations system, when he said, `It is inflexible. We have an inflexible and rigid industrial relations system'. Does the Minister support Mr Reith's view or was Mr Reith describing the system he supported under the Fraser Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in fact noted the comments of Mr Reith. I have always believed that the prerequisite to an opinion was to know something about what one was talking about. That clearly is not what Mr Reith thinks is a prerequisite to an opinion. He thinks that one can just simply fill an opinion out with empty rhetoric and windy observation rather than in fact portray any understanding about the details of the industrial relations system in this country. Indeed, when the coalition was in power it presided over a period of simple indexation and at the end of its period attempted to introduce a wages pause, which was all centralised wage fixation and inflexible and rigid in the classic terms that Mr Reith has used those words.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, in stark contrast, carried out a thorough reform of the Industrial Relations Act in 1988 and introduced, among many other reforms, quite important reforms to enable the parties to reach what are called certified agreements under the Act and contract out of the award system so that industry specific agreements can be reached, reflecting the aspirations of the workers in the industry and the management in that industry, segregated out of the whole of the wage fixing system.

As well, through the accord, we have been able to introduce ongoing and comprehensive reforms to labour market management and the industrial relations system in this country. The first and most significant is the ongoing process of award restructuring, which is an innovation of this Government-it has not been attempted by previous governments-which enables employers and unions to work at overhauling each of their awards to remove the traditional barriers that have been placed there over time and in a way which can improve their efficiency and productivity.

Additionally, in the Act we provided for an award flexibility clause, which the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has now taken up, in each particular award where the applicants to that award so seek it, to enable employers and employees to agree, within the framework of an overall award, on working conditions tailored to the particular needs of that specific enterprise. A number of those have been availed of in the period since this power became available. There are also award facilitative clauses, which have made awards less prescriptive on issues such as working time arrangements and work organisations.

All this has been done at a time when we have maintained the need for a centralised wage fixing system to be able to deliver aggregate wage outcomes consistent with our economic objectives. No policy that Mr Reith has ever advocated can give anyone in Australia any certainty that the Opposition has a view about how it will arrive at, in a budgetary context, an aggregate wage outcome for this country or how it will replace the present cooperative system of industrial relations that we enjoy in Australia and succeed in managing the economy in the way in which wages policy has been managed over the past eight years of this Government.

If we revert to the policies that Mr Reith espouses and those that the coalition was manifestly guilty of during its period of office, we will have confrontation, division and Australian being set against Australian. We will not have flexibility. I think that Mr Reith should undergo a quick course on what the accord stands for, what the Act means and what the provisions of the Commission deliver before he criticises this Government about a lack of flexibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Will the Minister tell the Senate what tests are carried out by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories on imported foods, and whether they are adequate to detect most food contaminants that are likely to be found in imported foods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question relates to a structure that was introduced by the Government last year, a structure which is geared towards protecting Australians and Australian consumers from the risk of imported food that may be contaminated. The program is coordinated by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, and all of the testing is the responsibility of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories. The structure is such that the Imported Food Risks Advisory Committee (IFRAC) identifies the categories of food that pose risk to human health, and those foods are then made subject to testing. It is a broadly representative committee which, importantly, constitutes representatives of State government health departments, consumer groups and importers associations as well as the Federal Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The program commenced in a limited way in April 1990 and was expanded in July 1990 to include a broader range of tests. Since April something like 2,183 samples of food have been tested under this program. The bulk of these tests have been for listeria in cheese, about 910 samples; microbiological contamination of prawns and oysters, 281 samples; and, in peanuts, aflatoxins, heavy metals and organochlorides, 428 samples. In that time there have been 141 failures out of those 2,183 samples-6.5 per cent-and most of those failures have come in a limited number of areas. Crustacea, cheese and coconut have very small failure rates, but prawns, oysters and peanuts are foods that have been identified as being an area of concern.

The results to date highlight a number of areas of concern and, as I said, those areas that should be concentrated on are oysters and peanuts. For instance, during October, 40 per cent of oyster samples tested for microbiological contamination and 20 per cent of peanuts tested for organochlorides or heavy metals exceeded the food standards code maximum residue limit. That food standards code is the limit that the IFRAC applies to ensure that the food that is imported and is being tested conforms with the domestic food standards code, a code which adequately identifies whether a particular batch of food poses a threat to the health of the community.

As I have indicated, those two areas of concern have been highlighted by the IFRAC and testing has been undertaken. Although in operation for less than a year, this particular program has already shown itself to be of potentially great advantage to consumers in this country in terms of ensuring that they are protected from public health risks associated with some imported foods.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is somewhat similar to Senator Giles's question, but I was told to address the question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) proposing to amend Australian food standards to accommodate the importation of pesticide contaminated Chinese peanuts? I am not too sure whether that was what Senator Bolkus was telling us about previously in his answer. He did mention peanuts, but he also mentioned a whole lot of other things. I specifically want an answer regarding pesticide contaminated Chinese peanuts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several portfolios could probably cover an answer to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question. I think the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, which of course used to fall under Senator Cook's supervision, has been sampling imported peanuts from all countries from about July of this year as part of its imported foods inspection scheme. In nine of 14 samples taken from batches of Chinese products, traces of the organochlorin benzene hexachloride (BHC) have been detected in the imported peanuts. The level of BHC residues detected was very small, less than 0.2 milligrams per kilogram. These levels are in fact comparable to those set for other food commodities which are widely consumed in Australia. For example, the Australian food standards code establishes maximum residue limits of BHC in meat of 0.3 and in milk of 0.1 milligrams per kilogram respectively. These standards apply equally to domestic and imported goods as it is not the intention of the NHMRC to promote health interests as an artificial barrier to trade. I know Senator Bjelke-Petersen is not suggesting that, either. The relevant data in this particular case have been assessed by the NHMRC Pesticide and Agricultural Chemicals Committee, which considers that consumption of this batch of Chinese peanuts, containing up to 0.2 milligrams per kilogram of BHC, should not present a hazard to human health.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite clearly, as with meat and milk products, there needs to be a standard set for the import of peanuts from overseas. I believe that appropriate levels will be considered by the Public Health Committee shortly, but I understand the concerns of peanut growers in Australia that the pesticides which are used as part of the agricultural production worldwide should, nevertheless, not persist, albeit at a level which results in damage to the health of consumers. In so far as Australian peanut growers take particular steps to ensure that public health is safeguarded, the same requirements should be made in respect of imported peanuts and all other foodstuffs. It is important to note that the Federal Government has announced its support for the labelling of unpackaged peanuts coming into this country so consumers will know the country of origin of those unpackaged peanuts and can make a choice-a choice which would support, I have no doubt, Australian peanut growers. The unleashing of the power of consumers in the marketplace can support these important areas of peanut growing which, of course, are of concern to Senator Bjelke-Petersen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a serious question for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce--

— Senator Knowles is drawing a long bow there. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald in which claims are made by manufacturers of audio cassettes and computer discs that the Government intends to remove the 17 per cent tariff on these products as part of the accession to the Florence Agreement and that this will `drive them offshore or out of business'? Can the Minister comment on the validity of these claims and on progress being made on Australia's accession to the Florence Agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a bit of comment in the newspapers about this issue and I am glad Senator Beahan noticed it and drew it to my attention so that I could correct the record. The Florence Agreement, as honourable senators know, is a 1950 international United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation treaty which provides for free trade in goods of an educational, scientific or cultural nature. The so-called Nairobi Protocol of 1976 extends that.

ANSWER.PARA: Seventy nations, including Australia's major trading partners, have acceded to the Florence Agreement and 21 have acceded to the Nairobi Protocol. The Government has indicated publicly an intention to accede to the Agreement, but before it does so, it is a requirement that all customs duties be removed on a wide range of things, such as books, documents, works of art, and so on. A working party has been looking at this; it has considered several options, one of which is the removal of the 17 per cent duty on blank magnetic recording media, in addition to tapes with recorded media on them. No decision has been made about this by the Government. We will consider carefully the issues raised by local manufacturers prior to reaching a decision. I emphasise again that a decision has not yet been made.

ANSWER.PARA: Despite the lack of awareness on the other side of issues such as this, when the contract was launched the Director of the Australian Information Industry Association, Bob Mounic, publicly welcomed the initiative. The Association, at least, appreciates the sorts of savings and efficiencies that can be achieved by this sort of approach in government. The approach fits very much within the concept of the new federalism initiative. It is a tangible outcome whereby State, Territory and Commonwealth governments operate together. It is also one which underscores the degree of complexity involved in trying to be consistent. In this case we had to achieve a contract which could be used across all the different legal systems in Australia and across all the requirements that those legal systems ensure are put in the way of obtaining consistency in contracting.

The Government does not intend to stop here. Other ideas were put forward at that conference to achieve the aim of reducing the cost of tendering for government business. The Opposition does not understand the direct impact of all that-that is, with reduced costs for tendering, Australian businesses can obtain greater access to government contracts. As a consequence, those businesses can get a bigger slice of the government purchasing cake.

All these objectives form part of the rationale for the move towards a common contract. At this early stage, it has been welcomed by industry. It has been appreciated by industry as having cost saving opportunities for it. It is a pity that those on the other side either cannot understand that or just do not want to.

TALK.START.PARA: — My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say that funding for local government is an issue under consideration by governments. In fact, it was discussed at the Premiers Conference in 1989. In terms of the actual levels of funding for government, we have a number of arrangements in operation. For a start, we have a financial assistance to local government scheme which operates under legislation that has been in operation for four years and which will be reviewed after mid-1992. That review will comprise representatives from Commonwealth, State and local governments. ANSWER.PARA: I am not going to respond to the political point scoring that Senator Calvert is indulging in here, but I ask the Senate to acknowledge that, when we talk about assistance from Federal government to local government, we are talking about some $700m of government expenditure. ANSWER.PARA: If the Opposition wants to come into this chamber and express some concern about people in the community who do not have financial resources, it just does not have the record. TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Government accept that the term `waste products' is no longer an appropriate term for recyclable products, especially now that considerable effort is being directed towards commercial re-use of used products such as sump oil? —I am asked whether the expression `waste products' is now redundant in light of current views about recycling. I say to Senator Bell that I think there may be some sense in that. The English language is a living language; it is an evolving language. It is quite possible that the expression `waste products' is redundant, although unfortunately there will still be a few waste products about. On that side of the House there will still be waste products-things that are infinitely incapable of recycling. In so far as the serious point of Senator Bell's question is concerned, I will make inquiries about that-it is an interesting sort of suggestion-and give him an answer in due course.

—I, too, ask a question of Senator Button in his capacity as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that the hearing into the meat industry resumed before Deputy President Riordan last Wednesday following the return of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) representatives from overseas? Is he aware that, whilst their absence was the reason for the case being adjourned, none of them have appeared before the Industrial Relations Commission hearings, and that the AMIEU has closed down not less than four meatworks for up to two days each since last Wednesday, bringing the number of strikes since 19 October to not less than 75? Does the Minister condone the actions of the AMIEU in misleading the Commission? Is the situation serious enough yet for the Government to intervene in an endeavour to bring some sanity to the meat industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Deputy President Riordan, who is hearing this matter, adjourned the hearings because of the absence overseas of significant union officials and company representatives who are on a mission to examine best practice in overseas meatworks. This mission was supported by this Government to try to improve the information base of practitioners on both sides of the industrial relations fence in the meat industry so that they can find better models of behaviour and practice in order to manage a more harmonious industry. That is one of the missions that we have supported to try to bring more rational coherence to the practice of industrial relations in the industry. I am aware that Deputy President Riordan saw this as significant and did not wish to proceed while those leaders of the industry and the unions were away. So the answer to the first part of the honourable senator's question is yes.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the second part of the question, the fact that AMIEU representatives did not appear at all is not abnormal. It is frequently the case-in fact almost universally so-that the people who appear on behalf of organisations in the Industrial Relations Commission are the professional advocates retained by the organisations. It is not usual for the leading officers of organisations to appear and argue in their own right. They retain counsel or industrial officers for that purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can give evidence.

—They can give evidence if they are called and if they are required to give evidence. They could do that, but that is not the point of the question. The point of the question is why they did not appear. The answer is that it is not usual and normal for that to occur. I turn to the third part of the question concerning the number of strikes. There have been a number of strikes in this industry. I have previously said that the Government does not condone any of them.
—What is your position?

—We want to see a harmonious industrial relations environment. But I do not take Senator Crane's view that in a highly disputatious industry such as this all the right is necessarily on one side and all the wrong is on the other. In a case such as this--
—What about the union abuses?
—Will you shut up and allow me to finish the answer. You are out of order.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Cook to withdraw.

—I withdraw, Mr President. May I also ask that Senator Hill be brought to order because I am sick and tired of him barking away like a little lap-dog at the fringe of a debate while I am trying to answer a serious question from Senator Crane. I do not assume that, because there is a high incidence of strikes, all the right is on one side and all the wrong is on the other. Therefore, I do not assume that I should barrack exclusively for one side and oppose exclusively the other side. I believe the appropriate course is for the Government to step back and enable the independent Australian Industrial Relations Commission to do its job, listen to the arguments, look at the particular circumstances of each case and make an adjudication in those circumstances based on the evidence before it. In that sense I do not condone strike activity. The reason we support the continued existence of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is so that it can do its job of preventing and settling industrial disputes. We believe it should be given the opportunity to do that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time the other day Senator Spindler asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, a question regarding non-cash incentives. I have now received a response from the Treasurer and, because it is of some length, I ask that it be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
BRIEFING ON LEASE INCENTIVES
- Where a business taxpayer is offered a cash or non-cash incentive to enter into a lease of business premises, the incentive will be income of the taxpayer.

- This position was confirmed in relation to a cash lease incentive by the decision of the Full Federal Court in Federal Commissioner of Taxation v Cooling 90 ATC 4472. On 16 November 1990 the High Court refused special leave to appeal against this decision.

- Mr Cooling was a partner in a firm of solicitors. The firm of solicitors was paid $162,000 as an incentive to procure the firm's service company to accept a 10 year lease of a whole floor of a building in Brisbane. Mr Cooling was assessed on his portion of the incentive payment, $21,060.

- It is the view of the Commissioner of Taxation that this decision extends to non-cash lease incentives received in similar circumstances, that is to encourage a business taxpayer to enter into a lease of premises to be used by the business.

- Non-cash benefits which have been offered as lease incentives include such things as rent-free periods, rent-discounts, cars, boats and paintings, free fit-outs, the payment of removal costs and payments for the surrender of the existing lease.

- The Government legislated in 1988 to ensure that non-cash business benefits which were not convertible to cash would be treated as if they were convertible to cash. These provisions will apply to lease incentives provided in similar circumstances to Mr Cooling. The provisions are contained in section 2lA.

- Section 2lA provides that if the non-cash business benefit would otherwise have been deductible, the benefit will be reduced by the amount of the deduction. This provision will have the practical effect that in relation to a lease incentive provided in the form of a rent-free period, the benefit will effectively be tax-free.

- The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that he is in the course of preparing a draft ruling which will outline the proposed treatment of cash and non-cash lease incentives, and on the penalties which will apply if a taxpayer has not disclosed the receipt of such a benefit. It is anticipated that the draft will be released to the public by the end of the year.

- Yes, the Government is aware that lease incentives are provided in the form of non-cash benefits. The legislation which was enacted in 1988 is considered to be adequate to ensure that these benefits are assessed in the appropriate manner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week Senator Walters asked me a question concerning the agreement between the Commonwealth Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and a legal opinion in relation to it. Honourable senators will recall that an agreement between the Commonwealth and the Guild was signed on 23 November and on the same day both parties sought a determination from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal that the agreement take effect from 1 December 1990. The Tribunal did not issue such a determination. In seeking a determination from the Tribunal, the Government had firstly obtained legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department which indicated that under the legislation the Tribunal was required to implement the agreement as soon as possible and that there was no authority for the Tribunal to hold a public hearing on the matter. Independent legal advice obtained by the Tribunal supported the advice provided by the Attorney-General's Department. However, it raised doubt over the description of parties entering into the agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: The agreement was between the Commonwealth and the Guild, whereas legislation refers to an agreement between the Minister and the Guild. This in the Solicitor-General's view is an arguable technical point. However, in view of the doubts raised and in order to promptly resolve the matter, action was taken to amend the agreement. Contrary to misinformation distributed by the Opposition spokesman for health, Dr Woods, this amendment had no adverse financing effects for taxpayers. The costs to the Budget had already been incurred as a result of the Tribunal's decision in November not to issue a determination but instead to call a public hearing to consider the impact of the agreement. A revised copy of the agreement was provided to the Tribunal on 7 December. In accordance with legal advice from independent and government bodies, the parties sought that the Tribunal cancel its hearing of 18 December and issue an appropriate determination as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage, traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ``The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth and as stated in our Federal Constitution-``Relying on the Blessings of Almighty God . . .''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.

4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that I reported to the Senate on 4 December 1990 on the concerns of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances with this instrument. Those concerns were that the instrument may not be in accordance with the parent Act, that discretions affecting individual livelihood may not be subject to Administrative Appeals Tribunal review, and that provisions empowering officials to enter premises may not include sufficient safeguards. The Committee has now received advice from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, which meets its concerns, including an undertaking to amend some provisions of the guidelines. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
13 November 1990
The Hon John Dawkins MP
Minister for Employment,
Education and Training
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Industry Training Agents' Guidelines No.l made under s.94 of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 8 November 1990.

Clauses 7 and 8 set out detailed criteria for qualifications and conditions for registration as an industry training agent. Clause 9 provides for the cancellation of registration as an industry training agent. A Note to clause 9 in the body of the instrument helpfully advises that where a registration is cancelled under s.93 of the Act then AAT review of the decision is available under s.95 of the Act. The Committee assumes that AAT review is also available for decisions made under clauses 7 and 8. If so, then it would appear useful to include similar notification of review rights in Notes to these clauses.

The Committee also raises the validity of cancellations under s.93 of the Act. That section provides that the ``training advisory body may cancel the registration . . . if the training body is empowered, under the guidelines, to cancel the registration.'' (Emphasis added.) There does not appear to be such a power in the Guidelines, apart from where a person has requested cancellation. Clauses 9.3 and 9.4 are drafted as if such a power exists, and the Note to clause 9 also assumes that the power exists. However, the actual drafting of clause 9.3, which seems to be intended as the relevant provision, does not include an express power of cancellation.

Clause 8.14 provides that a registered training agent must allow the training advisory body to enter premises and inspect or copy records and the agent must make the records available and answer questions.
The Committee would appreciate your advice on the relationship between these provisions and s.98 of the Act, which also provides full powers of entry and inspection of documents.

The Guidelines do not provide that persons entering premises under clause 8.14 produce any form of identification. The Committee normally insists that provision be made for such persons to produce photographic identity cards. In this context, s.98(2) provides for written identification and also provides that the person entering must leave on request if this identification cannot be produced.
Your advice is also sought on any penalty for a breach of clause 8.14 if an agent refuses to comply. Under s.98 there is a penalty of $1,000.
In addition, there appears to be no protection against self-incrimination in relation to the questions which may be asked.
Your advice would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely,
Patricia Giles
Chair
4 December 1990
Senator Patricia Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations
and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles
I appreciate the helpful comments and suggestions in your letter of 13 November 1990 concerning Industry Training Agents' Guidelines No 1.

The suggestion that appeal rights be footnoted under clauses 7 and 8 of the Guidelines does not seem appropriate. Clause 7, qualifications required for registration, and clause 8, conditions of registration, are not in themselves subject to appeal. Decisions and appeals concerning registration, which take account of these conditions, are provided in the Act itself.

There is no perceived relationship between subclause 8.14 of the Guidelines and section 98 of the Act. Section 98 of the Act empowers officers of the Australian Public Service to enter premises and inspect records relating to financial obligations imposed under the Act. Subclause 8.14 differs, since it refers to the powers of the training advisory body to enter premises, inspect records and ask questions of a registered industry training agent, in relation to determining whether the agent is carrying out its duties under the Act.

There is no intention to impose a financial penalty on industry training agents for a refusal to co-operate under subclause 8.14. As mentioned, there is no relationship between section 98 of the Act, which provides a penalty of $1,000, and subclause 8.14. Since co-operation is part of the condition of registration, the training advisory body is authorised to cancel registration and there is no criminal penalty to be imposed under the arrangement.
The matters raised in your letter which appear to require an amendment to the Guidelines are, in summary, as follows:
- removal of the requirement for a registered industry training agent to answer questions, to ensure consistency with section 98 of the Act.

- provision for procedures, including appointment of authorised officers and proof of identity, concerning access to premises and records of a registered industry training agent, in a manner consistent with section 98 of the Act.
- the need for express powers for the training advisory body to cancel registration where a registered industry training agent is of unsound mind or is undergoing imprisonment.
Attached for your consideration are clauses which have been drafted to give effect to the amendments.
I would be grateful if you would confirm that the proposed amendments are satisfactory so that I can make amending Guidelines in time for them to be tabled before the end of the current Sittings.
Thank you for your assistance.
Yours sincerely
John Dawkins

The role of the Office of Australian War Graves is very important. In the words of the annual report, it exists to commemorate individually the sacrifice of those Australian men and women who gave their lives during or as a result of their service for Australia and the Commonwealth and to maintain these commemorations.

Currently, the Office of Australian War Graves is responsible for the maintenance of 19,520 war graves and 3,336 memorials to the missing. As well, it is responsible for the erection and maintenance of standard memorials to eligible men and women who have died post-war. These number approximately 170,000.

The Office of Australian War Graves has been improving its administrative procedures, according to the annual report, but it is still experiencing some delays in achieving the target of completing all commemorations within three months. This is because graves cannot be dealt with within that time frame, for proper reasons, and also because applications are not being returned promptly. There is a need still to improve this system.
There are two other matters I would like to raise from the annual report. One matter relates to tenure, and page 9 of the report says:

Cemetery authorities are increasingly adopting the overseas practice of placing a tenure of 25 to 50 years on graves and crematoria niches. This has been strongly resisted on behalf of veterans but is likely to become law in some States. Where perpetual commemoration cannot be guaranteed, alternative arrangements for commemoration in our own Gardens of Remembrance may be necessary.

That brings me to the third matter I wish to raise from the annual report: the gardens of remembrance in South Australia and New South Wales. One can see that increasingly these gardens of remembrance are going to be extremely important. I asked a question of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) nearly a fortnight ago about gardens of remembrance in South Australia and New South Wales, and he was totally unable to answer it even though he is himself a South Australian senator.

There was a contract arranged in August 1988 for a new New South Wales garden of remembrance which would hold 100,000 plaques when completed, and it was to be the largest in Australia. That project has been unduly delayed by industrial problems, wet weather and contractor bankruptcy. As a result, the price of that garden of remembrance has doubled from $3.1m to a final cost of about $6.3m and its completion has been delayed for over a year. One can imagine what effect that outcome has had on the next of kin and the strains it has placed upon them in that context. In addition in South Australia, unsatisfactory specification of the work has created greater delays there. The annual report concludes on this aspect by saying:

The erection of the new Gardens in South Australia and New South Wales could only be described as disasters from the aspect of time, cost and quality. The employment of Australian Construction Services as the construction authority on any future major War Graves projects must be carefully considered.

What a scandal it is-with something so important to our national heritage, to the men and women who fought for this country, to the taxpayers of Australia-to see the waste and the incompetence of the management of those programs. That blow-out in costs is, I remind honourable senators, coming out of the Department of Veterans' Affairs budget, all because Senator Bolkus and his construction people cannot get their job done properly. Similarly, with the Concord repatriation hospital in New South Wales, there has been a blow-out of $5m which had to be settled a few months ago because that same Construction Services organisation could not run that job properly either-and, once again, that amount is coming out of the Veterans' Affairs budget.

We cannot afford to have wasted dollars like this when the need to look after our veterans is so great as they age. We cannot afford to have this scandalous misuse of taxpayers' money, this waste and this incompetence, just because this Government is not interested in administration or in looking after the interests of our veterans.

The period covered by the 1989-90 annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation has been notable for the great difficulty the Australian Taxation Office has been facing in coping with the consequences of so much legislation, much of it correcting previous deficient legislation, particularly in the area of capital gains. But the Australian Taxation Office has tended to diminish or reduce its costs, responsibilities and administration by transferring such factors to the taxpayer, with the result that there is now a minimum review of the assessment of the tax return as lodged. That is later followed up through a taxation audit.

The major problem facing taxpayers is self-assessment. There is an insufficient legislative base, with too great a reliance on income tax rulings, with the result that there has been a great deal of uncertainty before the law. That is not good in a democracy. Although tax agents and taxpayers, particularly the corporate taxpayers, have been requested not to lodge much of their documentation and paperwork other than the official limited information on the tax forms, many taxpayers are opting to ignore this advice and to provide more detailed information in order to protect their interests, including the minimisation of penalties as an insurance against possible future action.

The operations of the Australian Taxation Office have not been without some criticism. The McKinsey report testifies to this. Also, the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia has drawn attention to certain shortcomings in the administration of taxation law in Australia. The Government, of course, has no excuse for further delaying the first instalment of the tax simplification or the Green Paper, which was promised earlier this year and originally scheduled for August. It is now well overdue. However, we must commend the Australian Taxation Office for what it has done in terms of tax simplification. The report is with the Government. The criticism is not with the Office but with the Government. Sales tax simplification is moving along quite nicely and I would like to commend the Office for the work it has done.

The year has been notable for the passing of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5). This will bring to termination or to the grave many companies which will be unable to meet their tax commitments on 15 December. I call upon the Government to ease the requirement to pay tax on this date because corporations in these straitened economic times simply will not have that ability. We drew the Government's attention at the time of the passage of the legislation to the fact that it will certainly cause a cash crisis.

I also refer to the recent amendment passed by Parliament, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), whereby the Commissioner of Taxation can apply to a court of summary jurisdiction to have a conviction or order set aside for prescribed taxation offences. Generally, I must say, this has been applied with a great deal of discretion and compassion; however, not all States are using this provision, as is the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Tasmania, and I draw the Taxation Commissioner's attention to this law to ensure that the new Act is appropriately used in necessitous circumstances where judges are perhaps being a little too severe in imposing unreasonable penalties. However, I would like to commend the Taxation Office for what it has done in setting up the problem resolution sections. I believe they are working quite well.

I draw attention to the fact that the Commissioner of Taxation has signalled that an attempt will be made to deny a deduction for defence costs to companies which have been targeted for takeovers on the grounds that they are capital costs. There do appear to be certain circumstances where this is a harsh approach. For example, to deny a company costs which were statutorily incurred under the Companies Act of informing shareholders preparing a part B and part D statement appear to be not outside the normal accepted costs allowed under section 51 of the Income Tax Act. I inform the Senate that a lot of defensive action is really akin to an insurance policy. However, to the extent that capital structures were changed, the Deputy Commissioner would probably be right in denying a deduction in this particular area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to offer a few comments on the 1989-90 annual report of the Australian Commissioner of Taxation. I draw the attention of the Senate to page 138 of that report, which documents the enormous success of the fringe benefits tax which was levied for the first time by the Hawke Labor Government from 1985 onwards. We all know that before the fringe benefits tax was levied, in effect, a number of people were receiving non-cash remuneration. Tax avoidance was going on in the community; people were receiving part of their remuneration in non-cash forms.

SPEECH.PARA: For the first time in Australia's history, this Government decided to crack down on this effective form of tax avoidance by levying the fringe benefits tax. That tax was long overdue, and it is now generating enormous revenue for the Australian Government. According to this report, the value of fringe benefits amounted to $2.385 billion-over $2,000m worth of fringe benefits in the community. About half of those fringe benefits were in the form of company-provided motor vehicles, the value being $1.1 billion in that year. From the very important fringe benefits tax we are now collecting over $1,100m annually. It is now a $1 billion tax. Fringe benefit tax collections continue to come in ahead of Budget revenue predictions. In this Budget, the collections were $48m ahead of Budget predictions, as has been the case in most years with this particular tax.

The value of the fringe benefits that are now taxed is one measure of the prior amount of tax avoidance that was going on in the community by a privileged group which had company-provided cars and a whole range of other assets provided to them as benefits. We are now generating over $1.1 billion in extra revenue from this tax. It is high time the Opposition came clean and told us what it intends to do about this tax, because when we debated this tax in 1985, and later, Opposition spokespersons told us repeatedly and regularly that they were going to abolish the fringe benefits tax. The net tax collected was $543m, a very tidy amount of revenue-a sizeable sum. It is a very important tax which cements the basis of our personal income tax in Australia. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENTARY INSTITUTIONS, SWITZERLAND AND FRANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions, September-October 1990.

Senator TAMBLING: I move:
That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is presented to the Parliament in order that senators and members of the House of Representatives, and in fact any other interested person, can overview the activities of the Australian parliamentary delegation which visited Switzerland and France in September and October 1990.

The delegation also had the opportunity to attend the European Commission and North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) in Brussels, as well as participate very actively in the Council of Europe and the European Parliament in Strasbourg. In that respect, I am sure that senators will find the comprehensive report interesting and, in many respects, timely and topical.

The issues were addressed against the background of some very dramatic changes in Europe at the time of our visit. For example, German unification; the early consequences of the Gulf crisis, particularly as they would impact on east Europe; the entry of the United Kingdom into the economic monetary union; and the important considerations surrounding the mad cow disease that affected the beef price industry. The report addresses many of these issues and has now been presented to Parliament to enable a very comprehensive study of the current issues that are going on in Europe.

It is important to note that normally a report of this nature would probably not be presented to the Parliament until about March or April next year. The delegation members decided that, in view of the important issues that were addressed and canvassed, it was important that we bring the reporting date forward, which we have done. The delegation visited some four countries and it met across the table with approximately 150 politicians, commercial leaders and a very wide range of advisers to government and to the various institutions in Europe.

It is important to note that there are serious changes going on in eastern and central Europe and in the Soviet Union, which of course impact considerably on the capital requirements of Europe, the changing trade patterns, changes that are happening in the fields of education and technology and, importantly, the areas of defence and security, particularly those issues surrounding NATO. The changes in the east European countries bring with them dramatic social, trade and defence issues that have to be addressed.

All members of the delegation were struck by the fundamental changes that are occurring in the Soviet Union and are apprehensive and fearful of many consequences that could flow, particularly in the area of defence, which are now receiving considerable media attention several weeks after the return of the delegation. It is also important to note that the debate on the common agricultural policy of Europe continues. It has been highlighted dramatically in the last few days by the lack of resolution at the Uruguay Round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade discussions. There are important implications not only for farmers but also for the consumers in Europe. The implications that this will have on the Australian economy need to be seriously addressed.

Probably the only issue on which members of the delegation were not able to reach a common view this year related to our visit to the Chinon nuclear power station south of Paris where, not surprisingly, the views of members of the delegation were sharply polarised, as has often been demonstrated in the debates in this Parliament. Nevertheless, it was important that the delegation visited the Chinon power station on a day when the lid of the nuclear reactor was lifted and the nuclear uranium fuel rods were being changed. The delegation was able to observe many of the issues relating to the consequences of waste in the entire industry.

Throughout the entire delegation visit the issue that struck me most was the changes that are happening in tourism and those changes that are related closely to the environment. The report addresses in some detail the changes that will be required both for marketing purposes and for future environmental considerations by Australians.

I commend the report. It was a pleasure to represent the Senate this year on this occasion. The company of the other senators and members of the House of Representatives was convivial and, at the same time, very constructive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as a member of this delegation to speak briefly to the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions. As Senator Tambling has said, it was indeed a privilege to be a member of this particular delegation. I commend the report to members of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: On our visit to Europe at this time, we saw and heard many things which suggested to us that Europe is in a state of incredible change. The speed of change is enormously challenging to government. It is throwing up issues of profound magnitude. This report cites some of those issues and provides insights on it that we gained from the delegation.

I emphasise the importance of this delegation each year to European institutions. As honourable senators would know, on most occasions it is preceded and followed by a visit to a European parliament. On this occasion, we visited the Parliament of Switzerland beforehand, then Belgium throughout the visit to the European institutions and, subsequently, at the end of the delegation's visit we attended the French Parliament for some time.

It is virtually impossible to overemphasise the importance of being there. Our involvement in those forums and institutions is of vital importance, especially with the changing status of the European institutions. The report cites significant matters. I will touch on just two issues which are not mentioned in the report.

Firstly, I make the observation that the whole of Europe is trying to come to grips with the problem of agriculture, which has been an essential element of the recent debates on international agricultural policy. The fact is that European farmers are extremely productive. They produce too much and are being subsidised by their governments to produce less. They are also being subsidised to stay on their farms, but in doing so to produce less. This gives rise to an extraordinary contradiction really.

When we were in Switzerland it occurred to us in the course of our discussions that we were really talking about-if we view this process differently or laterally-governments subsidising farmers to become conservationists in situ. The Swiss Government is beginning to see quite clearly that it must keep its farmers in situ, that it is the farmers who are in fact keeping Switzerland as it has always been. Environmentally and, in every sense, culturally and socially, that is of profound importance. It is possible to view the money that we are paying these farmers to stay there and do that as being a process of subsidising conservationists in situ rather than encouraging farmers to be less productive, et cetera. In other words, we can see it in a positive sense rather than in a negative sense. I suggest to the Senate that this is the beginnings of the new perception about how we have to see this process of subsidising farming.

The second question which struck me quite vividly when we were taking part in the debates in the Parliament and the Council of Europe was that we are constantly living with the implications of the enormous changes of central and eastern Europe. The leaders of the new democracies in central and eastern Europe are saying to the West, `Teach us how to be like you. Teach us how to become market economies. Teach us how to become democracies of the Western style. Teach us to be like you.' I think we have to ask ourselves what we are going to teach these people; what sets of values we are actually going to transmit to them as being the appropriate sets of values of the post-communist era in a densely populated, increasingly unstable, increasingly poverty-stricken and, indeed, devastated part of the world.

I think that not only the political leaders of Europe but also the political leaders of the world, and especially of Western society, have to address this question seriously. Certainly, the answers that we received were that we have to teach them about development, market economies and dollars and cents-the implications as we have seen them for the last four or five decades in a prosperous and yet, in many respects, socially sterile and bankrupt Western set of values.

In some respects, I think that was the most profound issue that occurred to me while participating in this delegation. It is an invaluable opportunity for parliamentarians to visit and take part in these institutions every year. I commend the process of the delegation and specifically this report to the Senate. I thank my colleagues with whom I took part in this delegation. I congratulate its organisers and my colleagues on what I saw as a very positive and valuable process.
