DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill seeks to establish a statutory framework to secure the health and safety of Commonwealth Government employees while at work. In doing so, it will provide Commonwealth Government employees with the protection of modern occupational health and safety legislation similar to that which is presently enjoyed by both public and private sector employees in most States.

The incidence of occupational death, injury and disease in Australia, including in Commonwealth Government employment, is unacceptably high. On average, each week, over 3000 workers experience a compensable work injury resulting in a period off work of one week or more.

Apart from the human suffering involved, occupational injury and disease results in massive costs to Australian industry and the community through the need to provide medical and rehabilitation services, retraining and workers compensation schemes. There is also a huge cost through lost production. Working time lost in Australia as a result of occupational injury and disease has been estimated at around 10 times that lost through industrial disputes.

It is difficult to determine a precise estimate of the total costs involved. On the basis of the Australian National Accounts figures the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimated the cost of workers compensation claims in 1989/90 was $4.8 billion. This direct cost alone represents 1.3% of Australia's non-farm gross domestic product (GDP). If all the associated indirect costs, such as lost production and retraining were included, this figure would be much higher.

At a time when Australia faces considerable economic difficulties and is striving to improve its international competitiveness by improving productivity and holding down costs this is a cost which cannot be ignored. Every effort must be made to reduce it.

It follows that the reduction of occupational injury and disease should be seen as an integral part of efforts to improve Australia's performance through the Government's microeconomic reform program, including workplace reform through award restructuring. It is essential that consideration be given to improvements in occupational health and safety, when changes in job design and work patterns associated with award restructuring are being developed.

Mr President, these are the reasons which make improvements in occupational health and safety essential. Of course, this Government's commitment to improved occupational health and safety is not new. It is contained in the ALP platform and was included as a key factor in the non-wage element of the Accord. That commitment arose because it has been known for many years that Australia has a relatively poor OHS record.

In 1983 the Government commenced negotiations with the States, unions, employers and OHS professionals about the development of a national approach to occupational health and safety. In 1985 we established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission.

The fundamental aims of the Commission are to rectify the consequences of the previous fragmented and piecemeal approach to occupational health and safety and to provide a national focus for the development and application of uniform OHS standards and strategies. The Commission is thereby facilitating the development of a uniform approach to OHS across Australia and the most effective use of scarce OHS resources. This will avoid the duplication of effort which we as a nation can no longer afford.
An important element of the Government's overall OHS strategy is the development of legislation for the protection of its own employees.
Unlike other workers in Australia, Commonwealth employees are not covered by comprehensive occupational health and safety legislation.
In 1983, this Government commenced extensive consultations on the content of OHS legislation to cover the area of Commonwealth responsibility.
An important development which coincided with consultations on this legislation was an extensive review of compensation and rehabilitation arrangements for Commonwealth employees.

Mr President, the Commonwealth's expenditure on workers compensation in 1989/90 was $240m. Our compensation costs had been rising significantly for a number of years. The problem had to be tackled not only to reduce costs but to ensure that Commonwealth employees were protected from occupational death, injury and disease, and that injured workers were assisted to achieve a prompt return to work by effective rehabilitation and adequate and timely support, treatment and financial assistance.

The Government has created an integrated approach to prevention, compensation and rehabilitation. A progressive compensation and rehabilitation system was introduced under the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 and is administered by the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees (COMCARE). It is designed to minimise the human and financial costs of work-related injury and disease while at the same time providing adequate compensation and support for long term incapacitated employees.
Those reforms are complemented by this Bill. It aims to provide mechanisms for reducing occupational injury and disease that give rise to these unacceptable human and economic costs.
During the extensive consultation processes and the development of the resulting legislation, the Government was anxious to ensure that worthwhile improvements in OHS were not delayed unnecessarily.

Accordingly, after careful consideration of the direction of consultations and the likely content of the resulting legislation, the Government agreed to the implementation of interim OHS agreements between the management of individual public sector bodies and relevant unions. These agreements cover the detailed OHS arrangements to apply in individual Commonwealth bodies. It is not intended that this legislation override these arrangements except where any provisions of those agreements are contrary to the Act.
Mr President I will now describe some of the major features of the Bill.

The Bill is a comprehensive piece of legislation. A key aspect of the Bill is the emphasis it places on direct involvement by employers and employees in workplace OHS. Accordingly, it requires Commonwealth employers and employees in each workplace to take greater responsibility for the management of health and safety in that workplace. In this way it is consistent with the modern co-regulatory approach already adopted in most States of Australia and the A.C.T. as well as a number of overseas countries.

The legislation provides for regulations and codes of practice to be developed to cover specific problems. At the same time it imposes a duty of care on employers and employees, as well as manufacturers and suppliers of plant and substances, to take all reasonably practicable steps to ensure a safe and healthy work environment.

The Bill provides a framework for employers and employees to co-operate and consult in addressing health and safety matters in the workplace through the establishment of designated work groups and health and safety committees, and the selection of health and safety representatives.

The legislation will be administered by COMCARE, with a small core of permanent staff providing an advisory and investigation service. The service will assist Commonwealth agencies in complying with the Act, provide technical advice and have the power to issue improvement and prohibition notices and other orders and directions. In addition to the expertise of its own employees, COMCARE will be able to draw on outside experts, including State and Territory Government OHS inspectors, to provide advice and assistance on particular problems.

The Bill covers the employees of Commonwealth departments, statutory authorities, Government Business Enterprises and companies. Commonwealth employees will be covered in Australia or overseas, although not all provisions will apply overseas. The Bill covers persons employed by the Commonwealth under a law of the Commonwealth and of a Territory or under a contract of service or apprenticeship.

We have ensured that the legislation will not prejudice Australia's national security or its defence. It provides arrangements which enable particular provisions to be declared not to apply or to apply in a modified form, in relation to specified matters concerning national security and specified members of the Australian Defence Force. The legislation also provides for particular provisions to be declared not to apply in relation to certain covert or dangerous operations of the Australian Federal Police.

In addition, where the application of the Bill to a person who exercises a power or function under a law of the Commonwealth or a State or Territory would prevent the proper exercise of that power or function, regulations may be made excluding the Bill, or particular provisions of the Bill, from applying to that person.

Standards. An important aspect of the Bill in terms of the Government's commitment to encouraging a uniform national approach to OHS is that it provides for the adoption of standards and codes of practice which have been declared by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC). Where they exist, and are capable of relating to Commonwealth employment, these standards and codes will be adopted within the Commonwealth employment sector in all States and Territories.

Where there are no NOHSC standards or codes the Commonwealth will adopt the existing State or Territory standard, pending review of its appropriateness and applicability to the Commonwealth sector. There will, of course, be consultation with State and Territory authorities in these matters.

I am hopeful that the Commonwealth's intention to adopt NOHSC standards for its own employment area within all State and Territory jurisdictions, will provide further encouragement to States and Territories to implement NOHSC standards.

Mr President, I have mentioned earlier that the Bill establishes workplace arrangements which are an integral part of the concept of co-regulation, and provide the framework for ensuring the participation of employees in OHS matters, and co-operation and consultation between employees and employers.
I do not intend to describe these arrangements in detail. The mechanisms for their establishment, and their various functions, are listed in the Bill.

However, it is important to note a number of aspects in relation to the powers of the health and safety representative. He or she has the power to issue a provisional improvement notice requiring the employer to take corrective action to stop or to avoid a breach of the legislation.

In addition, in an emergency, where the representative believes there is an immediate threat to health and safety, the representative may order a cessation of work, but only when a supervisor cannot be located. If a supervisor is located, the supervisor has the right to decide whether work should cease. This approach has been adopted in most of the existing OHS agreements in Commonwealth agencies but has rarely, if ever, been used.

A health and safety representative who misuses his or her powers is liable to be disqualified by COMCARE from holding such a position for up to five years. The Government will closely monitor the activities of health and safety representatives and take whatever action is necessary to ensure there is no abuse of their power.

The Bill provides for an advisory function for COMCARE which will be most important in assisting employers, employees and contractors with their obligations under the legislation and in dealing with OHS problems. Use of the advisory facility may be a first step in an investigation process. I have already mentioned that the legislation enables COMCARE to refer requests for advice to experts outside the Commission.

Investigations. While the legislation's co-regulatory approach, which I have outlined here, emphasises co-operation in securing health and safety in the workplace, it is recognised that there needs to be effective enforcement of standards. The Bill provides investigators with comprehensive powers to enable them to adequately enforce its provisions.

These include powers of entry, and powers to issue prohibition and improvement notices to remove threats to health and safety or to stop or prevent breaches of the legislation. An inspector entering a workplace is required to carry an identity card and produce it upon request.

Appeals. The Bill provides for appeals against the decisions of investigators. In each case, the appeal is to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, referred to in the Bill as the ``reviewing authority''.
Sanctions. The Bill, provides, where a breach of the legislation occurs, that financial penalties can be imposed on Government Business Enterprises, or their employees.
Manufacturers and suppliers will also be liable to prosecution and fines for contravening the legislation.

Commonwealth departments and authorities which are not Government Business Enterprises may be the subject of a report to Parliament if found to be in contravention of the Act. Employees of such agencies may be subject to disciplinary action under the Public Service Act or other terms and conditions applying to non-Australian Public Service personnel.

The Bill is not intended to exclude the application of the criminal law in appropriate cases. Instead, it is intended that the criminal law of the States will continue to apply to Commonwealth employees to the extent that those laws are capable of concurrent operation with this legislation.

It is appropriate that I say something about the level of pecuniary penalties which this Bill imposes upon Government Business Enterprises and individuals who contravene the legislation. Those penalties have been set at levels which have regard to the range of penalty levels in similar State legislation. This is again consistent with the policy of striving for greater consistency in OHS legislation, standards and strategies and will ensure that persons who breach the Commonwealth legislation are penalised in similar manner to persons who breach equivalent State laws.

Financial Impact. The cost of implementing the proposals included in the Bill will be offset by savings already being achieved by COMCARE through the rehabilitation of long term compensation claimants and by a reduction in accidents in the workplace.

Five additional staff resources will be required by COMCARE in the first two years of operation and ten by the third year. This will involve a salary cost of 0.4 million dollars by the third full year of operation. Contract staff will be used to supplement the minimal permanent resources, at an estimated additional cost of 0.5 million dollars in the first year, decreasing to 0.2 million dollars by year 3.

There will also be some additional expenditure for essential operational costs. The total cost during the first three full years of operation will be between 1.1 and 1.4 million dollars per annum. The legislation will commence operation six months from the date of proclamation of the Act and, to facilitate this, ``start-up'' costs of the order of $0.3M will be incurred during the six months leading up to the commencement date.

In addition, individual agencies may incur additional expenditure to implement the workplace arrangements. The net additional cost attributable to this activity cannot be precisely estimated due to the wide variety of existing occupational health and safety arrangements currently in place in various Commonwealth agencies and the offsets and savings which will be associated with revised arrangements.

The provision of a safe and healthy working environment and the increased emphasis on co-operation to achieve such an environment is expected to reduce the incidence of accidents and injuries for which the Commonwealth would be liable. Implementation of the provisions of the Bill should, therefore, result in reduced Commonwealth expenditure on compensation and associated costs such as unnecessary retraining, lost time and sick leave.

Mr President, this Bill contains important reforms which, together with the compensation and rehabilitation arrangements already in place, will ensure that commonwealth employees receive the protection at work to which they are entitled.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleague for attempting what appeared to be the impossible and turned out to be so. The statement by me was explained the last time this matter was before the chamber so, without going back to do a synopsis of my previous remarks, let me go straight to the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 provides in clause 14 for a two-stage review by a designated presidential member of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission of the continued registration of unions whose membership is below certain levels. The first stage, under proposed section 193 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, will involve unions whose membership is below 1,000 members who are employees. The second stage, under the proposed section 193a of the Act, will involve unions whose membership is below 10,000 members who are employees-the figure being 10,000 because the proposal of the Government was recently amended.

The term `employee' is defined in subsection 4 (1) of the Act to include any person whose usual occupation is that of an employee. There are certain other classes of persons who, under sections 188 and 202 of the Act, may also be members of unions registered under the Act. These are not persons who come within the scope of the Commission's powers to prevent and settle industrial disputes and are therefore not relevant to the purpose of a union's registration.

Each stage of the review is to commence within the period specified for that stage in proposed new sections 193 and 193a. These proposed sections are closely modelled upon the present 193 of the Act, varied only in relation to the implementation of the two stages. Provision is made in proposed subsections 193 (6) and 193a (6) for the designated presidential member to cancel the registration of a union which does not have the required level of membership. This must occur if the presidential member is not satisfied that special circumstances exist that justify the continued registration of the organisation in the public interests.

An identical requirement exists in the present section 193 of the Act. This relates to the review of the continued registration of a union with fewer than 1,000 members who are employees. The Industrial Relations Bill 1988 had proposed a threshold figure of 3,000, but this was amended in the Senate to the present figure. Since the Act commenced it has become clear that the present provisions are not realistic requirements for unions participating in Australia's principal industrial relations system, which deals with matters of national importance in the economic, industrial and social fields. Trade unions must be capable of being effective partners with government and employers in achieving progressive changes in these areas. It is the Government's view that a federally registered union must, in the usual case, be sufficiently large and well resourced to take an effective part in the national industrial relations system. This view is also consonant with the voluntary activity now occurring in the Australian trade union movement to restructure itself, producing fewer and larger unions with greater industry focus.

Even so, as I acknowledged in my second reading speech, it does not follow that the national system has no place for unions with fewer than 10,000 members. It is precisely for this reason that a special circumstance exemption is to be available. A question has arisen about its width. There are two related elements to the proposed exemption. The first is the demonstrated existence of special circumstances. The Bill does not define the term `special circumstances'. This is deliberate; to attempt to define it would defeat the aim of providing a broad discretionary power. The objective is to provide a discretion which has flexibility and which admits full scope to take account of the facts of particular cases. The second element is that where there are such special circumstances, it is in the public interest for the organisation's registration to continue. It will be entirely for the designated presidential member, when exercising this discretion, to determine whether these elements are satisfied, but the discretion will not be exercised in a vacuum. A statutory discretion must be exercised having regard to the scope, objects and purpose of the Act in which it is found. In the case of the Industrial Relations Act, this requirement is reinforced by section 90. Under that provision, the Commission must in the performance of its function take into account the public interest and for that purpose have regard to, among other things, the objects of the Act.

The explicit objects of the Act are set out in section 3. Particularly relevant to the exercise of the discretion are the objects of promoting industrial harmony and cooperation among the parties involved in industrial relations in Australia, found in paragraph 3 (a); encouraging the organisation of representative bodies of employers and employees and their registration under the Act, found in paragraph 3 (f); encouraging the efficient management of the organisations, found in paragraph 3 (h); encouraging and facilitating the amalgamation of the organisations, found in proposed paragraph 3 (j); and encouraging and facilitating the development of organisations, particularly by reducing the number of organisations that are in an industry or enterprise, found in proposed paragraph 3 (k).

Against this background, depending on the circumstances of each case, the designated presidential member may decide that the elements justifying continued registration exist where, for example, any or a combination of the following criteria are satisfied at the time of the review: (a) whether there is any other organisation which can represent under the Act the industrial interests of the members of the small organisation and, if so, whether that other organisation is prepared to do so and would do so satisfactorily; (b) whether the industrial interests of the organisation's members are such that those interests would be likely to be better represented under the Act if the organisation remained registered; (c) the views of those members about which organisation should represent their industrial interests for the purpose of the Act; (d) the extent, if any, to which the organisation is attempting by appropriate means-for example, increasing its membership or by amalgamation-to obtain more than the required number of members and whether it would be reasonable to give it a further opportunity to do so; (e) whether cancelling an organisation's registration would be likely to harm industrial relations in the industries or enterprises of employers of persons eligible for membership of the organisation; (f) whether the continued registration of the organisation would be likely to contribute to good industrial relations in those industries or enterprises; (g) the organisation's record of active and constructive participation in industrial relations; and (h) whether the organisation is the major union in a particular area of economic activity of employers engaged in similar or related businesses.

The provision of these examples should not be taken to imply that any of them should be given any particular or additional weight by a designated presidential member when considering an organisation's continued registration, nor should they be taken to limit the matters which can be taken into account. The examples are simply intended to illustrate three points: firstly, that if a nationally registered union is unable or unwilling to increase its membership to the threshold level, it will be for that organisation at a hearing for the purpose to demonstrate that there are sound reasons for its continued participation in Australia's national system of industrial relations as a registered organisation; secondly, that the special circumstances test is not intended to be narrowly or rigidly applied; and, thirdly, that if it appears to a designated presidential member that there are good reasons in the public interest, in the context of the Act, for a union subject to review to continue to be registered, that should occur.

That concludes the statement and, as I said at the beginning of it, it is intended-and deliberately so-to be used for interpretative purposes in proceedings before the Commission where it seeks to interpret or understand the legislative intention of those amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that I rise at this point. I do so in recognition of the argument that Senator Durack has put and the fact that in a former government Senator Durack was an Attorney-General and therefore greater weight may be placed on his arguments than ordinarily ought to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I should say is that the central question of this debate is whether we have faith in the designated presidential member of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission-as, if you like, in colloquial terms, the umpire-being able to recognise what is the most appropriate circumstance to give effect to the broad objectives of the Act. The second question is: if we do recognise that role, given the specific reservations of the Australian Democrats and the Government's real commitment to the freedom of association convention, what is the best way to reflect our concerns?

There seem to be two options. The first option is to set out in the Bill, or sub- sequently in the Act, comprehensive amendments aimed at each conceivable circumstance. The problem with that is that we can conceive of a range of circumstances. This legislation is to stand for a considerable time, I anticipate, and I do not think it is proper for us to be cast in the role of trying to conceive of every circumstance. Indeed, where we are put in that position, often our imagination is found wanting, given that fact is frequently stranger than fiction. The second option is to invest in the umpire-in this case, the designated presidential member-the discretion, but to set down the particular guidelines as clearly as we can.

Having put it in simple terms, let me go to some detail. No matter how carefully the definition is drafted, it is highly likely to be subject in this field in the future to considerable argument and litigation. We recognise that whatever we write may be well the subject of argument and litigation. The examples that we might give would inevitably become the primary considerations in the reviews of the continued registration of small organisations and the focus for determinations by the Commission under the proposed sections. This may have the undesirable effect of drawing attention away from other matters that could be regarded as justifying a small organisation's continued registration.

The provision reproduces the existing special circumstances formula-that is, the present section 193-which was developed in consultation with representatives of the employers; in this case the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions at several of the meetings held by the National Labour Consultative Council. It was deliberate legislative policy not to qualify the expression `special circumstances'.

I should say it was deliberate for a number of reasons. There are other examples in Commonwealth legislation of the use of the term without any qualification-for example, in the Family Law Act 1975 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, with which the courts have had no difficulty and indeed have enjoyed some judicial support. As Fogarty J. of the Family Court of Australia has observed, it is:

. . . difficult and in a sense undesirable to lay down any precise definition of the meaning of or attempt to catalogue the circumstances which may constitute `special circumstances' [within the context of the Family Law Act] . . . it is desirable to retain its flexibility of scope and application to the facts of particular cases . . .

That judgment was in relation to the marriage of Schmidt (1979) 28 ALR 84, at page 95. Moreover, Burchett J. of the Federal Court of Australia has commented, in relation to guidelines under the Health Insurance Act 1973, which referred to special circumstances, that:

. . . it is particularly important that the broad discretions, created to give a lively flexibility to the administration of the scheme, should not by the gradual deposition on judicial decisions, become fossilised into rigidity . . . (t)hose discretions are intended to be applied to a great variety of situations.
That judgment was from Chee Keong Thoo's case (1988) 78 ALR 307, at page 323.

Therefore, defining special circumstances in one case would create uncertainty in relation to the meaning of `special circumstances' where used in other provisions of the Act, for example, section 189 which requires various criteria to be met for registration under the Act, including, for unions, a minimum membership size and being industry based and, for employer bodies, a minimum number of employees. Those particular criteria do not have to be met where a designated presidential member is satisfied that special circumstances exist justifying the association's registration.

Problems of interpretation may arise because it will be seen that the Parliament has given legislative guidance on the meaning of `special circumstances' in one context but not in another. The discretion is to be exercised not, as in the case of some important discretions under Commonwealth legislation, by a departmental subordinate of a Minister, but by a highly qualified, experienced and independent presidential member of Australia's primary industrial relations tribunal-the Australian Industrial Relations Commission-which has judicial status and whose decisions can be appealed to a Full Bench of the Commission.

I make that extended, somewhat legalistic, presentation in order that it be set down clearly in the record of this debate that the statement I have made concerning special circumstances is a statement which is deliberately intended to be accessed by a presidential member in a particular case for the purpose of determining the Government's intention in bringing it forward. Senator Durack has now raised the question of whether or not that is capable of being received by such a designated presidential member as guidance within the meaning of the Acts Interpretation Act and he has sought to quote from the Act. The first part he quotes are the words `ambiguous' and `obscure'. It may well be that Senator Durack sees nothing ambiguous and obscure within the terms that are set down in the amendments. However, I cannot anticipate what will happen in the future; I do not have a crystal ball and I am not gifted with prescience. In the volatile and robust field of industrial relations, I cannot anticipate what issues may be debated or how matters which call for judgment may arise. So I do not take the view that matters which are `ambiguous' and `obscure' may not arise in a proper debate before a commission concerning what the meaning of those provisions might be; nor do I say that my statement should not be taken as not being a part of the Government's intention and that the Government's intention should be limited only to what appears in a second reading speech. I deliberately prefaced my statement-in fact, I also concluded it-by saying that it was meant to be read as part of what the Government intended. Therefore, I would expect that in a case before a designated presidential member those words would be used as a guidance.

In summary, we either make the decision to vest some confidence in the umpire-the designated presidential member who sits close to the play of industrial relations, who observes the behaviour of the parties, who is knowledgable about the industries and is experienced in the field-to make the appropriate judgment, guided by these views as to what is reasonable, and to so decide, or we will clutter a Bill with quite extensive amendments which, by virtue of the way in which the law is expressed, cannot be discursive, elaborate, consider or imagine the various possibilities, and we then sit back and allow the profession of law to be practised at great expense to employers and unions in trying to uncover the real meaning of the legislation. It seems to me that the course being adopted by the Government and, in this case by the Australian Democrats, is an appropriate course. It is appropriate in any case, but it is especially appropriate in a matter such as this where the questions of what an exemption will be are very real and important questions.

The Australian Democrats have put it to the Government, sincerely and conscientiously, that they want a strong commitment from the Government which sets out the provision for exemptions; in fact, they have weighted their position strongly that exemptions can be obtainable in proper circumstances. The Government recognises, acknowledges and accepts that point. We, too, want to see that provision appropriately expressed in the legislation. Given the options, it seems to us that it is entirely appropriate, and indeed quite proper, that the amendment should be made and we accept the amendment, but it should be made as a caveat against a real knowledge of what is intended. When the second reading speech was delivered this amendment was not foreshadowed. At that point we could not have expressed our view of it. At this point, now that it has been moved, we can express our view on it and that is what I have done in my statement.

Senator McLean had quite a number of what he called `draft' amendments. I cannot see `draft' written on them. I have a copy here. —I give notice, Madam Temporary Chair, that at the end of the debate I will seek leave to object on behalf of the Party. Presumably there is a price when one has been bought. SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, as I was saying, that an amendment does not have standing until it is moved. We chose not to move this amendment. That is the point I was making before Senator Chapman interjected. We chose not to move it because we believed that there was a better way to do it, and the better way is what has just occurred. I understand that members of the Opposition are miffed by that. They are frustrated in their intention. Senator Durack used the expression that we `sold out on an amendment'. How meaningless is that? It is really an attempt to be emotive and to introduce pretty squalid stuff into a debate which is supposed to be about improving legislation-and that was our precise intent from the beginning.

The other day I paid some compliments to Senator Walters when I talked about her being a formidable opponent, about her being courageous, tenacious, determined and committed, but I qualified that by saying that she was also illogical, biased, prejudiced and selective. Let me quote some of the examples of the selectivity. Senator Durack was very selective in what he read out from the Acts Interpretation Act. He read out a section which said that this particular process had no standing, and he quoted certain sections from the Act. But he ignored section 15(AB) (2) (h), which goes on to explain that:
. . . any relevant material in the Journals of the Senate, in the Votes and Proceedings of the House of Representatives or in any official record of debates in the Parliament or either House-

has standing. He chose to be selective and to ignore the significant subparagraphs which acknowledge the point that we had made about the standing of the ministerial statement. He failed to refer to section 15(AB) (1) (a), which elaborates further upon the standing and the circumstances upon which this sort of material has standing.

Senator Walters was quite precise in her citing of specific sections of the ministerial statement when pursuing the usual union bashing line that she gets up with over and over again and, in fact, was very selective in what she quoted from the ministerial statement. The Act, the ministerial statement and the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill itself go out of their way specifically to build the process of exemption to the point of fairness. In the final analysis, all the propositions that are contained in this Bill are tested in the ballot box of any union. In the final analysis-from somebody who has been involved in social action movements for some years-the union movement, if it did not like what was being enacted here, could bring this process to its knees by its response to it, and that will be the final test as to whether or not it is an acceptable process. That is the final test as to whether or not any law works. That is the nature of what we are confronted with as legislators, and so it should be in a democracy.

Both Senator Walters and Senator Durack have been absurd in their selectivity. They have been illogical in their approach; they have distorted what occurred before we got into this chamber; and they are miffed by the fact that their intentions have been frustrated because, for some reason or other, they sense that we did not cooperate with them. Senator Walters posed certain specific questions about the attitude and position of the Australian Democrats in relation to International Labour Organisation (ILO) requirements of freedom of association. The Democrats are of the same mind as the Government that the provision of the existing Act, and especially as it will be amended by this Bill, should meet the requirements of the ILO provisions for freedom of association.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why the ILO?

—The honourable senator is wrong. That is not the position of the ILO. We are not signatories to those particular clauses, and the request is that we become so. There is no difficulty in our mind with the position that is being advanced both in the Act at present and as it will be amended by this Bill in terms of freedom of association.

SPEECH.PARA: The second question relates to what the Democrats' position is in relation to compulsory unionism. It has never changed in our 13 years. We do not believe that unionism should be or is compulsory in this country. The reality is that about 65 per cent of Australians are not members of unions. The proof of the pudding is in the fact that Australians are not compelled to be members of unions. The fact is that Minister Fahey in New South Wales recently chose to distort a major piece of legislation which was in excess of 300 pages long and to call it the Industrial Relations Amendment (Voluntary Unionism) Bill 1990 and that one clause of that Bill of 350 pages related to the question of voluntary unionism. He chose to distort the whole process, but that is not our way of doing things. The answer to Senator Walters's question is that we believe in voluntary unionism. There is voluntary unionism in this country today and about 65 per cent of Australians have chosen not to be members of unions. Senator Walters is grasping at straws.

Before we put this amendment, and presumably it will be done soon, I would like to turn to the question of the position of professional officers and members of organisations of professional officers. They came to us in strength and they put arguments to us on paper. They were good arguments, and we listened hard and long. Their argument was the fact that professional officers are in a special situation in relation to amalgamations and the requirement to amalgamate.

I acknowledge that in the second reading debate I referred to the Swedish model which takes them aside and addresses their circumstances as being special. But since then I am convinced of the fact that what we were being asked to do was to create a special class of people who did not have to prove under the Bill that their circumstances were special. In other words, it was inherently contradictory. If they have special circumstances-and I am convinced that they have-I believe that they will convince the Australian Industrial Relations Commission easily and those special circumstances will be acknowledged in the manner the Bill provides for. I do not believe there are any grounds for fear any more. I must admit that for some time I listened very closely to their arguments. I am now convinced that there are no grounds for fear. I do not believe I have to apologise to those people because I am convinced that the Bill as it will be amended will accommodate their requirements-and I am convinced of that by argument.

There is a final question which I would like to address just briefly, and the Minister for Industrial Relations may respond to this. The Minister is aware of the fact, as also is Senator Durack, that the Democrats had great concern about the standing of individuals in relation to industrial relations legislation generally. All of the industrial relations legislation in this country is very much organisation oriented; it does not overtly acknowledge the situation of individuals in the industrial relations context. We have always argued that we were not convinced that individuals could not be caught in impossible situations. In this place, as honourable senators will know, I have pursued the cause of John Ellenbogen in New South Wales. In the State jurisdiction he was caught as an individual in a most unenviable and unjust situation. I was concerned that this legislation might place individuals federally in similar circumstances.

The Minister will acknowledge the fact that that has been the subject of some considerable discussion. Senator Durack will acknowledge the fact that I had considerable discussion with him and Mr Howard about this matter. Senator Durack, as a former Attorney-General, assured me that the individuals were okay, that they had access to legal aid and that under common law they could pursue any difficulties they found themselves in in relation to their circumstances of contract with an employer. I am convinced therefore that the rights of individuals are adequately protected. Indeed, Senator Durack was one of the people who convinced me about it. Therefore we have backed off in relation to the rights of individuals in the context of this legislation, which has a strong organisational or collective bias to it.

However, I have discussed with the Minister, and with the shadow Minister and Senator Durack, the concept of an industrial ombudsman, because I believe this legislation has created fear among small organisations and individuals about their standing. I have advanced the suggestion that there should be an industrial ombudsman because I believe a lot of that fear is ill founded and unnecessary. I am convinced of that. I was not at first, but I am now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Shame!

—We hear derisive cries of `Shame, shame' from Senator Chapman and others-shame at the fact that we have an open mind, we listen and we can be persuaded. Honourable senators should be ashamed of the fact that they have closed minds, they hear nothing and they are not prepared to be influenced by any argument. That is where the shame lies-on the Opposition side of this argument. They exhibit bias, prejudice and selectivity and closed-mindedness. We cannot afford to bring that attitude to legislation because we hold balance and the legislation has to be improved by us, if at all possible. That is precisely what we are on about. I know members of the Opposition find that very frustrating, but it is just another one of the frustrations they will have to live with, whether in opposition or government. It seems to me it will be a damned sight more frustrating for them if they finish up in government with the attitude that they display towards our open-mindedness and objectivity about things.

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of an ombudsman struck us as being a way in which a lot of the unnecessary fear could be placated and we thought that an ombudsman could deal with a whole clutch of minor matters that would consume the time, resources and energy of the Commission at large, particularly when the Commission has been directed to undertake quite substantial tasks in relation to what we regard as an essential, positive, responsible and appropriate process of amalgamation, which this Bill is essentially directed towards.

I invite the Minister's comment on the concept of an ombudsman because I believe this is the appropriate time for us to consider the standing of individuals and to consider the possibility of an industrial ombudsman subsequent to this legislation making a positive contribution toward it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are your amendments?
—I do not have an amendment about the ombudsman at this stage; nor do you.
—Are you opposing it?

—I am putting the concept up. Can Senator Kemp not understand the fact that I do not have to be subservient? We do not have to be subservient to your requirements in terms of amendments. We are more fair dinkum than you are, you who have sat there and said that you will oppose any amendment that strengthens the Bill and support any amendment that weakens it. How fair dinkum is that? That is just totally dishonest. It is unethical. It is abandoning your responsibilities as law-makers. You are nothing else but politicians, hour after hour. Eventually you have to accept your responsibility towards the legislation. You have a responsibility towards the legislation that is before you and you cannot just blindly pursue this expectation that you have some God-given right to be on the other side of this chamber. In fact, the people will provide you with that right if and when they believe it to be appropriate.
—Senator McLean, could you address your remarks through the chair, please?

—Sorry, Madam Chair; I am just expressing my rejection of the fundamental position that the Opposition has taken in relation to this legislation-and, indeed, that I believe it takes to most legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I would like to seek the Minister's reaction to what I believe is a positive suggestion concerning, at some time in the future, the appointment of an a ombudsman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong this debate unnecessarily because we are not opposing an amendment. This example reveals the conduct of the Australian Democrats in relation to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill. I must repudiate Senator McLean's continually reiterated statement that the Opposition is taking a negative attitude to this legislation, that we want it to be weakened as far as possible. We not only want it to be weakened as far as possible, but we want to defeat it entirely, 100 per cent. We do not want it on the statute books. It is not a question of weakening it; we are opposed to it.
—You have not got the numbers.

—It will be Senator McLean's problem to explain to the electorate why the Democrats want to support the Government in this undemocratic process as far as unions are concerned. It is his problem to explain why he voted the way he has. We have voted against the second reading of this Bill. Perhaps we could have debated it further if there had been further time available, but, under the compression of the end of this session and the way the Government has managed the business, there is not the time. There is practically no clause in this Bill that we are in favour of or happy with, so for Senator McLean to keep reiterating here that somehow or other we are being negligent or not doing our job as legislators because we are trying to weaken the Bill is total nonsense. The fact is we are totally opposed to this Bill and we will be emphasising this again when we oppose the motion for the third reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened several times this afternoon to the Australian Democrats suggesting that we are unethical because we are not doing all we can to strengthen and support the Government's Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill. I really am totally bemused at the line that is being put. I sat in here and listened earlier, and I have just been listening again. I must place on the record that I do not believe that the position that the Opposition is required to take is one which says that our job in the Parliament as legislators is to strengthen the Government's legislation-either this or any other Bill. SPEECH.PARA: To suggest that it is unethical to take that view is quite beyond my comprehension. It is clear that because of the view that the Democrats are taking, the Government will get a great deal more than we would like it to. That is the nature of things. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support exactly what Senator Durack and Senator Reid have said. SPEECH.PARA: The following matters are examples of the matters in relation to which it may be directed . . . that preference is to be given . . .

That is, preference to union members. It is stated in this legislation that the Government is giving preference to union members. The first example given is preference for engagement in employment. The third example is regrading and the fourth is transfer. The fifth is retention in employment-first off are non-union members. TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Chapman. I remind him that the matters before the Chair are Democrats' amendments Nos 5 and 6. We have had a long discussion about compulsory unionism and a number of other issues. I do not think they are addressed by either of these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has made in relation to this clause this afternoon has been shown by my colleague Senator Durack to be largely irrelevant to the way in which the legislation would be applied by a court. That means that the onus for a union of fewer than 10,000 members continuing in operation and continuing to be able to represent its members effectively lies with the union. That is contrary to the principles on which this coalition would base any approach to industrial relations and that is why we oppose this particular aspect of the legislation. The amendments moved by the Democrats certainly ease that situation in some respects, but not in any really practical or applicable way.

SPEECH.PARA: The most important part of this statement by the Minister is not in relation to any effect that it might have on this clause of the legislation, but in relation to what it reveals about this Government's approach to government and legislation generally. It reveals what the Opposition has been saying for some years now is this Government's approach: it is a corporatist approach to the management of this nation's affairs. That is revealed on the second page of the statement where the Minister says:
Trade unions must be capable of being effective partners with governments and employers in achieving progressive changes in these areas.

Three segments of our community are singled out-trade unions, governments and employers. In other words, big business, big government and big unions. That is all this Government recognises. It does not recognise small organisations. It does not recognise individuals, not only in the sphere of industrial relations but in any other sphere of activity in this country. That is all this Government is about-fixes and deals between big organisations, between government, big unions and big business. That is something which this coalition will not have a bar of. That is why we are opposed to this legislation, because this legislation and this clause simply further entrench that corporatist approach of this Government to industrial relations in particular.

The arguments that Senator Durack has put for our seeking to weaken this legislation as much as we can-because we are totally opposed to it-retain their validity and are worthy of the support of this chamber. There is no doubt that this legislation does restrict quite severely the right to freedom of association. Freedom of association implies that an individual can form and join any organisation of whatever size he chooses in dealing with any aspect of our social life, including industrial relations.

This legislation will preclude an individual from doing that. It will remove that right from individuals unless they can appear before some presidential member and present arguments that it is in the broad public interest that their small organisation continues to exist, irrespective of their own wishes, irrespective of their own rights to freedom of association. Let us not hear any of this nonsense from the Democrats or from the Government that this legislation does not restrict freedom of association. Clearly it does, and clearly this legislation ought to be opposed.

So we are trying to improve the legislation. I think Senator Durack indicated he will support these amendments, presumably because he believes they do improve the legislation in the cause of small organisations and individuals. So the Opposition is going on with a whole lot of rubbish. The fact is that in the final analysis the Opposition-like the Australian Democrats-have to accept that we are stuck with this legislation and should try to improve it.

—We do not ideologically take the position of the Opposition. We are in favour of the process of amalgamation. I have said it over and over again: we are in favour of the process of amalgamation and, proceeding from that, we will do our own thinking. We believe we can improve this legislation in the cause of small organisations and individuals and that is exactly what we are trying to do.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not been bought off. We have not sold out. It will be a tragedy if the Opposition adopts that attitude if and when it is in government. Presumably the Opposition, when in government, will expect us to walk through its open door, sit with it and deliberate, and then be prepared to cooperate in getting its legislation passed.

If the Opposition gets into government, it will have to change its attitude because, frankly, it will need us to be equally responsible, open-minded and objective in supporting its legislation. It is not logical, reasonable or in any way sensible for the Opposition to argue that we should not listen and talk to the Government in an attempt to improve the legislation in support of small organisations and individuals. If something is going to be passed that affects the lives of Australians, it should be in legislation which is debated in the Parliament and it should be certain. The Democrats have been conned out of that. They have been conned into taking that out of legislation and putting it into some flimsy statement, which the Minister waves around when he refers to the Acts Interpretation Act. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the Australian Democrats have moved for 10,000 members instead of 20,000 does not mean that the date should be brought forward. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

SPEECH.PARA: The sooner we justly acknowledge the interests and needs of small organisations and individuals-which we have just done in the last amendments that were carried and which has just been done in the tabling and incorporation of a ministerial statement-the sooner we will get on with it. TALK.START.PARA: —We will accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to Senator Harradine's question, the Government has not consulted each of the other individual unions because we are aware that the ACTU for some time, at successive congresses of that organisation and in the consultations over several months leading to this legislation arising, quite minutely scrutinised these provisions in its industrial legislation committee. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just note that, despite the discourse of the Minister for Industrial Relations about his change of mind, I still cannot understand how a couple of years ago 3,000 was thought to be the right limit, although the Australian Democrats thought 1,000 was the right limit and went to the wall on it, and now it happens to be 10,000. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the question put by Senator Harradine, I think it is important for us to return, at least briefly, to the question of what the Australian Democrats see as the role of the numbers and the date. The intention of the Bill is to induce amalgamations because they are considered by the Government, by five major reports to government over the last decade and by the Democrats to be in the best interests of better industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, and quite within their rights, Opposition members do not agree with that. We happen to agree with it; it is a question of how we achieve that. As I said, in responding to Senator Durack and others the other day about what the numbers and the date mean, I think they are purely and simply mechanisms which will facilitate the process of induction.

I do not believe that the outcome for union limits will be 10,000 or that the date on which that will be achieved will be a prescribed date. It is `goals', spelt g-o-a-l-s-not `gaols', spelt g-a-o-l-s. It is a process of simply setting some targets if one believes in the idea. Nobody is going to finish up in gaol on the day after the prescribed date. The fact is that these numbers are a facilitating process. Other mechanisms have been put in place to facilitate amalgamation. The federation process is another mechanism of facilitation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is another con.

—It is a mechanism of facilitation. Senator Chapman should open his mind. If we believe in amalgamations and if we believe in trying to make the system fairer, which is what we have attempted to do in the last couple of amendments and what has been attempted by the tabling of a ministerial statement, it is not unreasonable to set these goals.
—We don't believe in amalgamation.

—I know that the Opposition does not believe in amalgamation; we do. The Democrats do believe in amalgamation, therefore we will have to set some goals because the earlier goals were not working for all sorts of internal reasons. It is not true to say that most unions do not accept the process of amalgamation. Most of them are toiling away at it and identify with it. The ones that are not doing so, for very good reasons, will be acknowledged when they argue under special circumstance. They have been facilitated in the process of arguing special circumstance by the amendments that have just been passed.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the amendments have facilitated and strengthened the exemption provisions. These amendments suggest that we should get on with the process. In the last 10 hours of debate, we have tried to make the system fairer, to acknowledge the requirements of individuals, to accept that there will be organisations of special circumstance and to enable us to get on with carrying out the legislation once we have made it better.

We will not be forced to adopt the inflexibility, the intransigence and the lack of objectivity which is the stance of the Opposition. That is not our way. We simply see the numbers and the date as being reasonable, achievable goals. To answer Senator Harradine's question, we believe that they are achievable because we have consulted with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) about them.

We offer no apologies for the fact that we consulted with the ACTU. I offer no apologies for the fact that I sat down with Brian Noakes for three hours in Sydney, and consulted with the Confederation of Australian Industry. I offer no apologies for the fact that we acknowledge that the National Labor Consultative Council has endorsed by and large a substantial proportion of the Bill. We are prepared to be persuaded by all this.

These are the facts about what is occurring. It is a fact that much of the union movement has been discussing the process of amalgamation very positively for quite some time, but the goals were not strong enough to get them to get on with it. That is the intention of prescribing a number and date. If people want to be obsessed about it and want to fail to see that it is purely and simply a mechanism, they can be so obsessed. We offer no apologies for thinking about what would be the most appropriate numbers and dates. We are offering suggestions which are acceptable to the ACTU and to the Government and which will probably be legislated for now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean has not convinced me to support his amendment. He mentioned that over a number of years there have been a number of reports suggesting that there ought to be amalgamations. I agree that these reports have come in. Various Ministers for industrial relations have urged amalgamations-and I include here some coalition Ministers. I have taken the same view with them as I take now. Successive governments have viewed union restructuring, such as amalgamations, on either an industry or an enterprise basis, as something of a panacea for improved industrial relations outcomes.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I have to say that industrial relations outcomes are not determined by this type of union restructuring. The fact of industrial life over a period of time is that industrial relations outcomes are determined more by the desire of the parties to see that a particular system of industrial relations works than by the size of individual unions.

The reason put to us with the Viner legislation was that, because of all the demarcation disputes, one needed an altered structure of trade union movement. As I recall it, the worst example of a demarcation dispute was between a fitter member and a boilermaker member of the same amalgamated union. I do not accept that industrial relations outcomes are primarily determined by this sort of union restructuring, particularly if it is a forced union restructuring, because individual members of those organisations who are loyal to those organisations may ultimately be so incensed with it that they, too, within their own craft, may take individual action which will be regarded as a demarcation dispute.

Going to the other questions that have been raised by Senator McLean, I very much doubt that the industrial legislation subcommittee of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and particularly the ACTU Executive, have given their approval for this shortening of the time. As I indicated previously, even if the industrial legislation subcommittee, the ACTU Executive or the ACTU officers say something, that is not necessarily to be regarded as the ultimate determinant of whether something is passed by this chamber; but it is of importance in this case because it affects the individual registered industrial organisations of employees for which the ACTU speaks.

Therefore, I would have expected the Government to be able to come into this chamber and say whether or not the ACTU has agreed to this reduction in the time allowable for amalgamations to take place. As I understand it, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is not able to say that. The Minister, in his response, said that he has had discussions with the ACTU on the Bill. Senator McLean said that he has had discussions with the ACTU and others on the Bill. That is good and fine. We have here an amendment to a Bill which goes to the question of the time allowed for organisations to conduct their negotiations as to which union is most suitable for their members to be transferred to-compulsorily-under this legislation.

Senator McLean says that the unions are busy on amalgamations. I can tell the Committee that there is a mad scramble out there at present to see who is going to end up on top. I do not feel that that is an appropriate way of going about it, and it is going to be worse if this time is truncated, as is suggested by this amendment. Let us hear what the ACTU has said about this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner we were talking about the period before amalgamation takes place being reduced by 12 months. I find it quite extraordinary that the Australian Democrats-in view of the argument put forward by them on the previous amendments that we dealt with, and supported by the Government through the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), about wanting, as I understood them, to make things fairer and less difficult for the small organisations that will be forced into amalgamation through this Bill-are now going to make it more difficult for them by this amendment. SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the likely pattern of this type of legislation, and picking up the Minister's words in previous debates when he was looking at industry unions, it is far more likely to be the medium sized industry organisations or employee organisations which would find amalgamation more attractive-I emphasise the word `attractive'-in the marketplace, not by compulsion, which is the effect of this. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As people will not only be reading what is said in this debate but also be listening to it, I think it is important that they hear very briefly why we are prepared to put forward this amendment, why the Government is prepared to support it, why the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) is prepared to support it, and why we have not been lobbied heavily about it. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a couple of comments from the point of view of experience in this particular issue. For a long time the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union and constituent bodies have been carrying out amalgamations. Originally there was the boilermakers and blacksmiths amalgamation; then the sheet metal workers with the boilermakers and blacksmiths into the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union; then the shipwrights and amalgamated metal workers into the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, then the AMWSU with the metal foundry union, going back to the AMWU; and finally, there was a recent vote by the AMWU in terms of amalgamation with the architects and draughtsmen's union. They voted 74 per cent in favour of amalgamation and the draughtsmen's union, with its first experience, voted 55 per cent in support. The point I make is that provided there is sufficient time to carry out the process that is necessary to achieve those amalgamations, that is all that is necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Comments of a broader nature have been made which I would like to put to rest. There was a comment by Senator Harradine that the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union had problems with demarcation arguments between its members in the fitting and boilermaking categories. I say very clearly that for many years there were many destructive disputes and stoppages between those two types of tradesmen when they were in separate unions, but following their amalgamation into one union-particularly in Queensland-they ceased immediately to the point where organisers of the previous unions did not even have to attend to those problems by talking to people about commonsense. In fact, a single organiser-he may have been a boilermaker, a fitter or a sheet metal worker-was able to go out and talk to people on the job who might have made a difference, and to clearly indicate a process of reaching agreement on work allocation.

I challenge anybody in this chamber to tell me about demarcation disputes, particularly in Queensland, where there have been many stoppages, as I said, of a wasteful and destructive nature. That amalgamation achieved the process of eliminating demarcation disputes-not disputes that one would have to talk out while people continued on the job, but disputes that created stoppages. I would like to point out also that the process of amalgamation in that particular organisation always followed a lot of communication with members, at all times looking for the maximum amount of democratic say by the members. They understood that, and that is why on every occasion they voted for amalgamations.

Many people talk about the rights of those in smaller organisations. One could look at the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union amalgamating with the shipwrights union, the latter union with 2,000 members in Australia and the former with 150,000. Of course, we wrote into the rules, at least for a period of two years, protection for the officials of the smaller union. In that amalgamation we also made a decision-without the assistance or direction of anyone else-that some 200 members of the shipwrights union would be better off in a seagoing union. We ran a ballot-they decided for themselves and went to a seagoing union. That is the type of operation that can be carried through by amalgamating unions with good faith.

Today, the national Secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, with some 180,000 members, is a person named George Campbell, the former secretary of the shipwrights union. It was a question of recognising his capacity to carry out the job, and that he would treat equally all members of the union movement in terms of what was in their interests. As a result of those amalgamations many things have occurred in the area of education, looking after people's compensation claims, understanding the law, and being able to negotiate through problems with employers who previously would not have had the capacity, the skill or the knowledge to do it-there would have been a dispute. When they knew that we had the information that they had, then they had to negotiate in a more meaningful way, and we have been able to argue those things through without any problem with regard to disputes.

On the other side of the coin there are those smaller unions which have as officials people who want to be big fish in little pools. There is a problem dividing the trade union movement in terms of politics. Some people have a particular ideological position in the political spectrum and they are more concerned about seeing their brand of politics-even if it is within a party-accepted by the trade union membership generally. They look at amalgamation on the basis of politics and ideology. Let me say clearly: that has never been the position with the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union.

It should not be the position of any trade union which wants to amalgamate. The bottom line should be what is in the interests of the members. Is it suitable that they should amalgamate? In the process, should certain groups of members be given to other unions because it is more appropriate? That is in the minds of many. As I said a moment ago, we have a situation where people want to remain as they are-big fish in little pools. They have no concern for the ordinary trade unions-the rank and file-and the sorts of improvements that have a spin-off for all workers in industry.

Those people, I must say, clearly have to be dealt with. They should be given an opportunity to make a choice. They must consider what are the interests of the membership and take action reasonably quickly without undue haste or force. If they decide selfishly and say, `We don't care about the membership and future membership. We reject all the logical and correct arguments that can be proven statistically by figures and experience, because they stand in the way of our personal position', then they have to be dealt with fairly effectively and quickly.

Of course, one of the things that quite often is not considered in this debate is that certain people on the other side really hate unions unless they are tame cat unions. Where there is that sort of situation there is a problem. Very often people are not concerned about how amalgamation affects the community. The amalgamation of all of those unions which are now a part of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union has made a great contribution to the community and the community's interests. I think that this amalgamation process should continue and that people should be given that opportunity. If not, there should be some government action taken.

No union with a membership of under 10,000-that is now the figure-can properly service its membership, do the research necessary to give the information to the negotiators, start to develop policy positions in terms of safety on the job and look at the social issues that affect the union members or their families. Trade unions are not just about working 9 till 5 or 7.30 till 4 o'clock; they are about the total concerns and interests of the workers' families and the workers themselves. Any union with less than 10,000 members does not have the capacity to service its members properly in that regard.

Even the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, which will have 180,000 members, will still find itself unable to carry out, in a perfect fashion, the role that should be expected of it in an enlightened society. Of course, people who are members of unions with under 10,000 members do not have any hope at all. These unions will become refuges for non-unionists-people who want to freeload on the system and take the benefits out of the system. Let us have a trade union movement that is effective on behalf of its members and which makes the necessary and proper contribution to the community. I think the process of this legislation will achieve that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.
