TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 15 of the Bill repeals an existing division relating to the amalgamation of organisations and substitutes a new subdivision which deals with a number of matters which are of concern to the Opposition-and, apparently, in some respects to the Australian Democrats, because they also have an amendment in relation to one of them. However, one of the early parts of the new clause 15, on page 12 of the Bill, seeks to insert a new section 237 in the Bill which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) An existing organisation concerned in a proposed amalgamation may, at any time before the closing day of the ballot for the amalgamation, use its financial and other resources in support of the proposed principal amalgamation and any proposed alternative amalgamation . . .
It may do so on condition that the committee of management of the organisation has given notice of the resolution and has resolved that it should so use the resources of the union.

This proposal appears to be a new provision from those that are in the existing subdivision of the Act relating to amalgamations. There is provision in the existing Act and in this new subdivision for official Yes and No cases for and against amalgamations to be lodged and to contain no more than 2,000 words. Those Yes and No cases are sent out with ballot papers to all members of the unions concerned with the proposed amalgamation. I suppose that is modelled on the Yes and No cases in a referendum under the Constitution; there seems to be some similarity.

The previous Act apparently was silent on the subject of whether or not a union with financial resources could use those resources for more propaganda in favour of an amalgamation by a union. Recently, however, a decision of the Federal Court of Australia has prevented organisations from using their resources, after the day on which notice of an amalgamation ballot is given, to promote a particular result in the ballot. That seems to be clearly the reason why the Government now has inserted this proposed new section 237, which I have paraphrased. The result now is that there would be a firm statutory provision that the proponents of an amalgamation, who are the officials of the union or those acting on behalf of the union, could use the resources of the union to promote the Yes case.

However, there is no equal provision for any of those who wish to support the No case to go beyond what is sent out in support of the Yes or No cases with the ballot papers. People opposing the amalgamation, unless putting up a proposed alternative amalgamation, are not able to use the resources of the union. The view from our side of the chamber is that the Federal Court decision is fair in preventing the resources of a union from being used to promote a Yes case and from being used to promote any particular result, either the Yes or the No case.

The section that the Government wants to insert now would be of assistance to only one side, namely, those promoting the Yes case. The result would be clearly unfair and of benefit only to one side of the amalgamation process, namely, those who are in favour of it, whereas in the old legislation, and in other sections of the new subdivision, the balance and equality of treatment of those who are proposing the Yes and the No cases are preserved.

It seems to be very like the situation which this Government proposed in relation to the referendum in 1984 when the Government announced-it did not bother to come to the Parliament to do it-that it was going to spend about $2.5m to support the Yes case. The Senate, with the support of the Australian Democrats, introduced an amendment to a referendum Act which was going through the Parliament at the time. That proposal of the Government to create what would have been a complete state of unfairness between the Yes and No cases in that referendum was prevented by a vote of the Senate, which amended the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act to prevent the Government from spending taxpayers' money on additional promotion of the Yes case; if the Government party or the Opposition party had wanted to spend the money out of their party funds, that was a different matter.

There is a very close parallel of thinking here because the Government is giving a special privilege to the executive of a union to spend union funds promoting an amalgamation-the same as the Government had it in mind to use taxpayers' money for the same purpose in a referendum to alter the Constitution.

For those reasons, the Opposition is opposed to this new clause. We believe the decision of the Federal Court is the right position, and that is the one which should be preserved and not altered by inserting this new division, which seeks to replace the existing division dealing with the amalgamation of organisations.

Here again we have the very clearest indication of the extent to which this Government is prepared to go to force the process of amalgamations. Not only do we have these very firm provisions in the legislation which we have been debating-because of their draconian nature, if unions remain with fewer than the 10,000 membership limit they will be subjected to cancellation of their registration if they continue in that state and do not proceed with the amalgamation process-but in addition to that the Government has in other provisions made it unnecessary to have a secret ballot in certain cases in these amalgamations.

The Government has accepted the Democrats' amendment to accelerate the process further and the Committee has just taken a vote. In this particular clause the Government is giving clear favour in the propaganda war in an amalgamation to the union which is supporting it and which will be enabled by this legislation to use its funds-funds which are likely to be very far in excess of those that would be available to those who are promoting the No result.

Here the Government is giving legislative force to a clear preference for one side of the argument in one of these amalgamation ballots, and creating a position which is totally unfair to the other side of the argument. This is in fact not a clause we can simply vote against. It requires an amendment to delete it from clause 15. I move:
Clause 15, page 12, proposed section 237, lines 6 to 19, omit the section.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 15, which runs to some 20 pages, is one of the key clauses of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill. Firstly, it replaces the existing amalgamation provisions of the legislation with provisions which explicitly recognise union federations under proposed new section 236. Secondly, it introduces a proposed new section 253h which provides an exemption from the necessity of having a secret postal ballot of members to approve amalgamation. A secret ballot of duly constituted meetings of members can suffice to approve an amalgamation. These provisions are designed by this Government, in effect, to make a merger of unions all but a fait accompli.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most important factors in achieving mergers as almost a fait accompli is allowing the establishment of federations of merging unions which are recognised by law and which can act on behalf of unions before industrial tribunals while the merger itself is being put in place. Allowing votes in favour of a merger to take place at meetings of members, instead of by what this Government and its Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) masters regard as the time consuming and counterproductive method-although obviously the far more democratic method-of a postal ballot, is another part of this agenda of the Government to try to make mergers a fait accompli. This is, of course, a much less democratic means of achieving mergers and amalgamations, because we all know that what happens in many meetings of unions when ballots are to take place is a sort of thuggery and intimidation.

Senator Durack has already referred to the provision in this clause which frees up union funds and available resources to promote the cause of the merger, but of course there is no provision in this legislation for funds to be provided to those who are opposing the merger. This is the first time that legislation has expressly authorised unions to use members' funds to campaign in support of amalgamation. Also, apart from the fact that there is no requirement for opponents within a union to be funded to present the campaign against that amalgamation proposal, there is no provision in the legislation for any particular union which might oppose amalgamation to be able to use its funds to campaign against amalgamation. In other words, this legislation is all one way. Members' funds can only be used to promote amalgamation, whether or not the union or all its members want that.

There is no provision for a union to use its resources to campaign against amalgamation. There is no provision for particular members of a union who might be opposing amalgamation to be provided with union funds to campaign against that amalgamation. The only provision for any case to be put against an amalgamation is, as Senator Durack said earlier, the formal 2,000 word argument which is sent out with the ballot papers. This indicates very clearly the one-sided nature of this legislation and indicates to us why it ought to be opposed.

The provisions for federations of unions to be established are completely unnecessary, because most unions would already have such provisions within their own constitutions. The inclusion of those provisions merely pre-empts the result of any subsequent ballot on the part of union members in terms of amalgamation. Union members are not required to vote with regard to the establishment of a federation, but acceptance by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission of a proposal to federate will undoubtedly be represented by supporters of an amalgamation as approval by the Commission for the unions to amalgamate.

Again it is part of this attempt to establish a fait accompli process on the part of the Government and on the part of the ACTU in favour of amalgamations. The practical effect of allowing the establishment of federations under this legislation will be to reverse the onus of proof for those who are opposing amalgamations. Again, the Opposition sees in this provision the dice weighted against those who want to oppose amalgamations; it is weighted against them both in the provision of resources for them to oppose the amalgamations and in the structures which will be established in terms of the process of amalgamation. This legislation and in particular clause 15 warrant the strongest possible condemnation and opposition from this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment by the Opposition. The Opposition put several arguments in support of this amendment. Let me try to deal systematically with those arguments in the way they have been put, starting with the last speaker, Senator Chapman, and his last point about the federations.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Chapman does not know or chooses not to recognise is that the process of forming federations is seen as a step towards testing whether it is thought by the members of a particular union or both unions in the federation, or any number of unions in the federation, that going the whole hog towards amalgamation is desirable. It is like an engagement before one is married or a try-before-you-buy type arrangement. Federations can be terminated in one of two ways. They can lapse, whereby the unions then go their independent ways and do not amalgamate, or they can be terminated by the process of actually amalgamating and forming a new third union.

To characterise this provision as anything other than something that strengthens the rights of union members is to misrepresent it, because union members can have a chance to find out what an amalgamated organisation would be like to be in and then form a judgment within the time period and exercise their vote as to whether they will proceed. It is something that encourages the process of involvement in democracy and something in which the manifest benefits or disbenefits, whichever they may be, can be apprehended by the individual members and by the organisations. In addition, because an amalgamated organisation is a legally recognised federation, it can have some standing in law and be taken as a serious arrangement and not as some informal arrangement reached by organisations acting in whatever individual way they may choose. I submit that `federations' is not a basis for moving this amendment; it is a basis for supporting the legislation.

I move to the next point, which was about the waiving of secret ballots. I wish that someone in this debate would complete a full sentence or a full explanation. Why does the Opposition simply say that under this legislation secret ballots are able to be waived? In the first place, secret ballots are not able to be waived anywhere. The difference is whether one has a postal secret ballot or a secret ballot held in a workplace. Who makes the decision about which of those two choices will be used? The person who makes that decision is the designated presidential member; that is, the Industrial Relations Commission makes it. Why does the Commission make it? It makes it on a basis of determining-that is, the umpire deciding-whether it is appropriate for the particular industry making the application, whether it has a tradition of meeting in authorised stop-work meetings, as the Waterside Workers Federation does, and whether in those authorised stop-work meetings the most democratic way is not to have a secret ballot on the premises with provision for absentee voting, rather than to send through the mail dry and arid reading, as it often is, to individuals in their homes to make a decision about and then often to find that the ballot papers are not returned.

What is the fairest and most democratic way of deciding? The body which will have that call is not the Government or the union but the Industrial Relations Commission, the umpire. If the umpire is satisfied, he then has an option. It is an option that he can choose to accept. I wish that in the discussion of this item that point would be made clear.

The fact that it is not made clear and that it is militantly ignored perhaps could lead to speculation about motive. I do not intend to engage in that speculation now, but it certainly is not a motive driven by an impartial and objective analysis of what the choices before the Commission are and how the amendment will benefit the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order as to relevance. I may be on the wrong tram, but I understood that we were debating a proposition for the deletion of lines 6 to 19 on page 12. I just cannot see anything about that in what the Minister is saying. I acknowledge that he is replying to something that Senator Chapman said, so maybe they are both out of order.

—I can accept that point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman, and I will move to the next point. Senator Harradine is right that I should not be drawn unnecessarily simply because the debate is off the point. I thank him for correcting me.

SPEECH.PARA: I now go to the first point relating to the matter before the Chair, though it is the last point on my list of matters that Senator Chapman raised. He said that under this provision unions cannot use their resources to campaign against an amalgamation. This betrays a breathtaking ignorance of what in fact this legislation is all about.

An organisation will have made a decision whether it chooses to amalgamate or not. If it has made that decision, it will obviously campaign in support of that decision. It is not a situation, as Senator Walters said in her contribution, of a big union attacking a small union and trying to take it over and of that big union funding the campaign to take the control of a union away from the management committee of the small union. That is not the situation.

The unions are independent entities until they are joined in amalgamation. It is the management committee of each that can decide whether to spend money in support of the pro case for its own organisation. It is not a situation in which the organisation can be authorised in any way to spend money on a campaign in another organisation. This is not a situation of a big fish swallowing a small one; it is a situation of each organisation, true to its sovereign right, being able to exercise, through its management committee, the policy and objectives of that organisation.

That brings me to the main argument put by Senator Durack. He proceeded to do a very dangerous thing when he put his argument, an extraordinarily dangerous thing in a debate of this nature-he argued by analogy. He argued that something applied to a constitutional referendum, ergo it applies in a union situation. Argument by analogy is interesting. It works if the analogy is true on all points, and if it is not true on all points the analogy fails because of that inconsistency.

It is not true to say that a union is the same as a parliament. Neither a union nor any other organisation that is a proper organisation has an in-built provision for an opposition. In a union, as in any social club, sporting organisation or any other organisation of any sort, there is an election process which determines the management committee of that organisation. It does not have an opposition. The management committee is elected to represent the views of that organisation.

The question now arises as to how that election should be conducted within a union and whether it is fair. I have to answer to that question, `Yes, it is'. It is fair for the reason that this Bill prescribes how union elections will be conducted and at what interval they will occur. It requires, as well, that rules of a union be presented to the Industrial Relations Commission before that union will be registered. It provides all of those things. That guarantees that union elections shall be fair. Therefore, one must accept that the outcomes of those elections represent the views of the organisation.

As soon as we arrive at that point, we say, `Can a properly elected representative body of an organisation have a view about the future of that organisation in a potential amalgamation?'. It is foolish to say that it cannot. Clearly it is there to govern and manage the affairs of the organisation; clearly it is there to have a view. In fact, many of its members would lean on it and seek advice from it as to what they should do in a particular case.

The other argument that is raised is that the Federal Court of Australia found in a certain way in a particular case. Until the Electrical Trades Union and Australasian Society of Engineers case was taken, it was believed that management committees had this right. It was a surprise to everyone that the Federal Court found as it did. We are proposing to correct the unintended consequence of that finding, and there is nothing exceptional or unusual about that.

The meaning of the law can only be adduced after a court decides. If the meaning of the law is found by a court not to accord with the will of the Parliament, it is appropriate for the Parliament to make the correction. That is all that the Government is doing. We are doing this, moreover, with the support of the National Labour Consultative Council (NLCC), the tripartite body representing employers and unions in this country, which both support this amendment and which have both said that they support this amendment.

Lest the argument now be raised that the Confederation of Australian Industry is somehow `big employers', let me tell the Committee that the CAI is the one organisation in this country that mostly represents small employers, because members of the Confederation of Australian Industry, unlike the members of the Business Council of Australia or unlike, as is often the case, the members of the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors or some other employer group, are smaller companies. The CAI is saying, through its representatives in the NLCC setting, that it supports this proposal by the Government.

When we consider that the object that is being added into this Act is to encourage and facilitate the amalgamation of unions, we see that it would be passing strange indeed if we denied an opportunity for those very unions to have in the amalgamation process the facility to promote the purposes of that amalgamation. They must do so, in my view, if they are conscientious about amalgamation, but there must also be a safeguard.

In a situation such as this there always has to be a safeguard, and there is. The safeguard is that, if a management committee wishes to promote the benefits of an amalgamation, it must advise its membership in advance that it so intends and enable that membership to engage in a process of seeking equal time to promote a counterview, if there is a body of membership of reasonable size that wants to do that; or to provide by resolution of the organisation, within the terms of that organisation, that the management committee should not proceed to do that. So there is a safeguard there and a let-out for ordinary union members if they wish to run against the prevailing view of their elected management committee, and properly so.

To carry this amendment would be to deny the democracy inherent in the way in which unions elect their memberships and to deny the democracy inherent in the leadership of an organisation being able to express a view about the future destiny and policy of that organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a load of rubbish. TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as the Minister has said, that in the event of an amalgamation proposal being raised the large union and the small union would have made a decision to amalgamate. SPEECH.PARA: If it is agreed that one of the most crucial of all decisions that an individual unionist has to make is whether that organisation will continue as it is currently registered with its eligibility rule as it is or whether it will be discontinued in that form and continued in another form with an expanded eligibility rule, why can the funds of the union be utilised only for one side of that proposition? If the funds of a union are utilised in a union election the court will declare that what has occurred is unreasonable and unjust.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—That is right, as the Minister said. It will be agreed that the election of office-bearers for the next three years is not as important technically-it might be important politically-as a decision as to whether the union will continue in existence in its present form. As has been indicated in this debate, the court has held that union moneys-that is to say, moneys provided by the persons who may be voting against the proposition-should not be so used and that is the crux of the matter. The Government is saying by this clause that a number of unionists do not want the amalgamation to take place.
—You may.

—You may or you may not. In that event the Government is really saying: `Not only are you not going to be paid or get anything to put your case, but we are going to take some of your union subscriptions to be used against your view'. —You are not quite saying that. You are saying, `This is what we intend. These are the processes of the organisation. If you disagree with what we intend, use the processes of the organisation properly to have our stated intention changed'. That is vastly different.

—I acknowledge the Minister's interjection. There are provisions in the legislation for a statement to be made if the committee of management decides that a statement should be made against the amalgamation. Money is not allocated to the campaign for the No proposition. The No proposition will go out with the ballot papers, as will the Yes proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is saying that those people who do not want an amalgamation to take place have got rights in the lead-up to the decision taken by that particular union as to whether it ought to amalgamate. That is true; they have their rights in that instance. The Minister is saying that once the decision has been made by the majority, everybody should stick to it.

That is not the end of the matter. If one is going along that track, what is the need for any of these provisions at all? There is no need for any of these provisions. I am sure that the members, who do not want to see their union amalgamate with another, would take a very dim view of the committee of management using its funds in a campaign to do what they do not want it to do. Therefore, it is my view that either there is a provision for moneys to be spent on the No campaign or the Yes campaign-it would be a very difficult task to decide how much unless it was even-handed-or one takes the view of the court in the Electrical Trades Union case where no union money was made available at all for the Yes or No propositions.

That the amendment (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

Originally, there was an error in the drafting of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill which gave rise to some concern in the constituency at large about the possibility of certain office-bearers being provided with the opportunity, by virtue of a drafting error, to be in office for an extended period. The original draft provided them with the grace of an additional four years in office even though they may well have served about four years prior to amalgamation. In rare cases-and they would have been rare but we had to acknowledge the possibility-that would have given rise to their being in office for eight continuous years without facing their members. Should they be fortunate enough to achieve a further amalgamation, they may be blessed with a further four years, et cetera. That was not the intention of the Government, and it has since been acknowledged as a drafting error.

We are trying to come to grips with what is a reasonable thing in terms of continuity in office. It is a fact that office-bearers will be affected by amalgamations and that they will be called upon to forgo careers. Many people will be impacted quite severely in many ways by this process of amalgamation. We are now specifically addressing the circumstance of office-bearers. We are really trying to address what is a reasonable thing. We begin from the premise that four years is a reasonable period of office for an office-bearer in an organisation. The Democrats have sought to rectify the original drafting error with an amendment which provides for a minimum of four years continuity. It is possible that some people will have more than four years in office, but not more than two years after amalgamation.

The purpose of this amendment is to achieve an outcome whereby, as a result of the process of amalgamations, officebearers are assured of their four years in office. Should a substantial portion of that occur prior to the period of amalgamation, they have the grace of an additional two years. Therefore there is the possibility-it is a fairly remote possibility-of a maximum in the vicinity of six years. But certainly there will be no roll-over provision whereby the people can go on using the process of amalgamations to extend their time. The objective of Democrat amendment No. 9 is simply to come to grips with that anomaly to ensure fairness in terms of continuity in office. Amendments Nos 10, 11 and 12 deal with consequential requirements.

This Government has had all sorts of flip-flops on the foreign ownership issue to the point where it went into the last election with a policy that said, `We have no policy', and that is precisely what it was about. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on an important matter relating to student unionism and the National Union of Students (NUS), which is holding its annual conference at Deakin University in Geelong this week. The National Union of Students was formed three years ago; I believe its anniversary is this week. This organisation has an income of around $800,000 per annum, derived from student union fees. Of course, in Australia membership of the NUS is compulsory for every student on a campus affiliated with the union. The constitutional provisions of the union render disaffiliation from the NUS at best difficult and at worst practically impossible. Despite this, since the union's formation in 1987 Liberal and other conservative students have denied the union $750,000 in membership fees through successful referendums and other campus action.

SPEECH.PARA: This student union purports to represent 250,000 students and holds itself out before university administrations and governments to be the official voice of students. This is what I would call a fairly invalid claim, in that only some 25,000 students across Australia have ever actually voted to become members of the union. I fail to see how the NUS can claim to be representative of the majority of tertiary students, when major campuses such as the University of Sydney, the Australian National University and the University of Queensland will not have a bar of the union.

The National Union of Students is like many other bureaucracies. Last year, the union spent about 80 per cent of its budget on wages and administration, and concedes that it spent only roughly 9 per cent on education. For a national union of students, it is fair to say that that performance is fairly dismal.

The NUS has a series of policies; in my eyes-somewhat biased I would admit-what I would call fairly irrelevant left wing student-type policies. One can go through policy after policy, but I will not bore the Senate tonight by referring to all of them. I will just mention a few to give an indication of what the NUS gets up to with the compulsorily acquired funds of students across Australia.

For a start, the union supports the inclusion of lesbian and gay content across undergraduate curricula-something that not even the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) would propose, I guess. I ask just what homosexuality has to do with engineering or economics courses. I am not quite sure.

At last year's conference held at La Trobe University the union resolved to campaign against real estate agents, which is most offensive to me, bearing in mind that was one of my previous incarnations. The reason for this was that the NUS blamed real estate agents for discrimination against women in the housing market.

At the conference about 12 months ago the union passed a bill of students rights. That bill, amongst other things, said that students had the right to work not more than 38 hours a week. I am sure many of the students who are attending the conference this week might wish to amend that bill of students rights and suggest that students be given the right to work even a few hours a week. In fact, I am sure many students would like the right to work 45 or 50 hours a week to meet the rising cost of living.

NUS support for the Australian Labor Party is undeniable. Last year the NUS resolved to campaign in opposition to the coalition's higher education policy throughout the Federal election. A marginal seats campaign was undertaken and publications were produced and distributed which attacked the Liberal and National parties' policy-using, I repeat, compulsorily acquired funds from people who had no choice but to pay those fees.

The point I wish to refer to tonight-and the reason I am speaking tonight-is a matter of grave concern which calls into question the proper administration of the union and which challenges the conduct of those elected to student political office. The National Union of Students has five elected student office bearers. Amongst these office bearers is the important position of General Secretary, which is held by Mr Andrew Wooldridge. In the financial reports of the union, which were released today at the national conference of the union at Geelong, it was revealed that in addition to his yearly wage of $19,000, Mr Wooldridge also claimed $17,690 in travel and other allowances. This is, in itself, a wanton abuse of students' money, but it is not the primary expenditure about which I am concerned tonight.

Amongst other things, the duty of the General Secretary includes responsibility for the administration and financial operations of the union and a responsibility for the national secretariat office which is located in the Melbourne suburb of Carlton. The regulations of the union impose several responsibilities exclusively on the General Secretary. Those are: the approval of all payments and loans and the requirement to act as a co-signatory on all cheques. In other words, the General Secretary has considerable authority and power and, next to the President, has a most responsible position in terms of the administration and operation of that union. One would expect only the highest standard of integrity and honesty from someone holding such an office.

But it has been alleged that these standards have been breached in perhaps the worst manner possible. It transpires that no fewer than 22 charges have been laid against Mr Wooldridge in relation to an alleged misuse of a cheque drawn on the account of that union. The amount of the cheque is believed to be in the vicinity of $4,500.

I have before me the minutes of an emergency meeting of the National Union held on 29 October 1990. These minutes reveal that the national executive ratified the actions of the NUS President who suspended the General Secretary after receiving written legal advice and who assumed the powers and duties of the General Secretary. On that same day-29 October-the General Secretary tendered his resignation in a letter written to the national executive. The resignation was accepted by the executive at the emergency meeting which then vested the powers and duties of the General Secretary in the President.

At the conclusion of the meeting a very short public statement on the matter was made. I would like to refer to that release and I seek, with the concurrence of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, leave to table the minutes of the meeting and also a notice that was put out today in relation to that.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The notice stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The General Secretary of the National Union of Students, Andrew Wooldridge, has resigned. This follows his being charged in relation to misuse of a cheque drawn on the account of the Union.

The importance of this was that Mr Wooldridge was due to appear before the Melbourne Magistrates Court on 4 December 1990. I have been informed by the Melbourne Magistrates Court that Mr Wooldridge failed to appear and that a warrant has now been issued for his arrest. I make no comment tonight about Mr Wooldridge or his alleged actions as the matter is now before the courts, but I will, however, comment on the handling of the matter by the other NUS office bearers.

The NUS President was aware of the charges against Mr Wooldridge up to a fortnight before the emergency meeting was held. The emergency meeting should have been called at the very moment that the NUS President became aware of the charges. Given that the NUS constitution requires that only 24 hours notice of meeting be given and that its meetings can be held by teleconference, the appropriate action should have been taken against Mr Wooldridge at a much earlier date. Instead, the NUS President, Kate Deverall, chose to engage in a cover-up which was worth about $80,000 to the union.

Between the time that the NUS President became armed with the information concerning the charges against Mr Wooldridge and the date of the emergency meeting, the union was engaged in two referendums relating to membership of the union. They were at Macquarie University and the Queensland University of Technology, where students were voting on membership of that union. So what, one might say, but victory in the referendums on those two campuses is worth approximately $80,000 a year to the NUS. Both were very hard fought campaigns and the NUS spent a considerable amount of money on both of those campuses. Both elections were won by the NUS. Had the charges against Mr Wooldridge been known on those campuses there is no way that students at these universities would have voted to be part of such an organisation which is shrouded in such allegations of potential corruption.

What does that say about the administrative procedures of an institution that will permit activities such as is alleged to have occurred? The attempted cover-up continues. At the NUS conference today in Geelong delegates were issued with a guide to the conference which contained a statement on the matter by the current NUS President, Ms Kate Deverall. The statement reads:

As you would all be aware the Union's former General Secretary has recently appeared in court on charges relating to alleged embezzlement of Union funds. While this unfortunate matter continues, it would be legally unwise for any Member of Conference to make any public comment on the matter whatsoever for fear of contempt of court or other problems. This advice comes from the Union's solicitor. Therefore I must appeal to all delegates to respect this position and refrain from commenting on what is undoubtedly the most unfortunate episode to have struck the Union.

Unfortunate indeed. The purpose of that statement is to stifle debate on this issue and withhold the circumstances surrounding the matter from the very people who should be fully informed of these events-ordinary students who have been forced to pay for this indulgence, possibly even criminal indulgence.

The union has failed the fundamental test of propriety and, as such, has proved to be totally unaccountable to the thousands upon thousands of students who are forced to pay union fees to this corrupt institution. Is it any wonder that Liberal students vowed to bring down this union soon after it was created in 1987. Cries of `I told you so' must now be bellowing through the corridors of student unions across the country.

The actions of the NUS leadership have been the inevitable consequence of the corrupt regime of compulsory student unionism which props up the NUS. Without compulsion the union would be forced to be accountable to its members. Surely no right-minded individual can now stand up and defend compulsory student unionism given the scandalous events that have transpired within the NUS.

I hope that those students who are attending the conference this week appreciate the weight that now rests upon their shoulders in considering the future of the union. They should recognise that NUS has been an abject failure. It has failed to provide any tangible benefits for students which it prides itself on doing. It has also failed to provide accountability and it has failed to demonstrate propriety. Its very existence should now come under question.

In conclusion, were a national union of students formed through a voluntary amalgamation of student campuses across the nation, which have themselves been formed voluntarily, the sort of corruption I have referred to tonight would not happen because the leaders of those unions at the campus level and at the national level would be accountable. Indeed, they would have been called into question for these sorts of improprieties a long time ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to express once again my concern in the strongest possible way about the misuse of parliamentary privilege. I refer to the speech made in the House of Representatives on 6 December 1990 by the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Wilson Tuckey. In fact, to describe his contribution as a speech may only dignify what was a cunning exercise in dirty politics. Mr Tuckey has justified this recent outburst on the grounds that in 1980 the honourable member for Fremantle attacked Mr Tuckey for his conviction for assault. That is a shallow excuse for a dirty attack against one of the most honest Premiers Tasmania has ever had.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Tuckey's so-called speech implied two things: first, that the legal system in Tasmania played favourites with the Premier, Mr Field, when he was charged in 1973-74 with a crime; secondly, that Mr Field received a light sentence for what Mr Tuckey described as a serious crime. On the first matter, Mr Tuckey implied that the magistrate trying Mr Field in 1974 and the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, Sir Guy Green, who heard the appeal, went soft on Mr Field because of political interference. Mr Tuckey said it is:
worthy of inquiry by a royal commission to guarantee the public of Tasmania that no outside influence was attempted by any person or any member of the then Labor Government.

It is obvious that the innuendo by Mr Tuckey is absolutely objectionable and it casts aspersions on the honesty and integrity not only of the magistrate but of the Chief Justice, Sir Guy Green, who has had a distinguished career as a judge and as the Lieutenant Governor of Tasmania under governments of two different political persuasions. Included also in Mr Tuckey's attack is a suggestion that the chief judicial officer, the Attorney-General, the late Mervin Everett, or other politicians close to him may have influenced the outcome. Given the integrity and the reputation of the Chief Justice and the Attorney-General, Mr Merv Everett, all of that is impossible. Just as relevant, of course, is my own observation that Michael Field, like me at the time, was an unimportant branch member of the Australian Labor Party who held no office and was probably more concerned with issues related to uranium mining, civil liberties and other idealistic areas of political activities. For Mr Field to be able to pull any strings at the time or have any strings pulled for him is plainly ludicrous.

Second, Mr Tuckey has tried to imply that the Tasmanian Premier Mr Field at that time was guilty of a serious crime that warranted stronger penalties. I have known Mr Field personally from that particular period right through, and I have known him in many situations. I know that all the parliamentarians he came into contact with, both on a personal and professional level, regarded him and still regard him as absolutely honest and a decent person. In fact, he is the quintessential honest man.

I also suggest that the matter for which the youthful Mr Field was prosecuted was an unusual one in that he was the victim of a rather revengeful and silly person who probably set him up, to put it in the vernacular. As is his style, Mr Field then took it on the chin and suffered the consequences, one of which was the loss of his teaching career. I also add, not only for this chamber's benefit but also for the benefit of Mr Tuckey, that the then Labor Minister for education would not interfere in order to save Mr Field's teaching career-so much for Mr Tuckey's view that Mr Field got off lightly.

I am very unhappy, Mr President, that parliamentary privilege has once again been used by Mr Tuckey to attack the reputation of honest people; namely, the Chief Justice, Sir Guy Green; Mr Field; the unnamed magistrate; and the Attorney-General, Mr Merv Everett.

We have seen a similar misuse of parliamentary privilege by Senator Newman when she attacked the former President of the Returned Services League, Sir William Keys, calling him a Labor stooge. On a previous occasion, she has attacked a Canberra public servant in a similar vein. I say tonight that this Parliament and all parliaments, whichever chamber we happen to be in, must recognise that parliamentary privilege exists for a very specific purpose; namely, as a protection for parliamentarians who must raise contentious issues that are demonstrably in the public interest. It exists for their protection against defamation and for no other purpose. If it is to be used for personal attacks on people, either through implication or innuendo, and if attacks without substance against individuals who are not in this chamber are to be the order of the day, then the question of parliamentary privilege will be queried all around this country.

On many occasions I have had the opportunity in this place to defend my reputation against individuals outside this Parliament. For example, in a defamation case I was involved in a number of very smart people in the literary world, for example, said, `It's totally up to Senator Aulich to redress the balance and to put his case in this Parliament under parliamentary privilege'. As I said on radio in reply to that, `I have no intention ever of using this Parliament as a place to either vindicate myself through the personal attacks on people who cannot defend themselves in this chamber--

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that over your court case last year?

—No, it was not over that. I will not ever use this place to attack an individual who does not have the right to speak directly in this chamber. In many ways, this Parliament has to look carefully at parliamentary privilege-not only at the way it operates now, but also at what we plan to do with it in the future. Otherwise, in the end, we may well lose it. The example of people like Mr Tuckey, in his attack on the Premier about an incident which occurred many years ago, is no benefit at all for this Parliament, for Mr Tuckey or for politicians in general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to the misdirection of Federal funds and the peddling of misinformation by the so-called environment movement in Tasmania. As most honourable senators would be aware, after a decade of conflict and numerous inquiries which came down on the side of industry but were not implemented due to a lack of political fortitude, the forest industries of Tasmania agreed to participate in the Salamanca process proposed by the then Labour-Greens accord.

SPEECH.PARA: This process, designed to achieve consensus between the warring parties, has been lauded by Federal politicians, Senators Richardson and Cook in particular, and has been advocated as a model for other States to follow. Participants in the process in Tasmania include the Government, unions, industry, farmers and the Combined Environment Group. It was heavily financed by the Federal Government and had a budget in excess of $10m.

Fellow senators would also be aware that when the process ended, the resultant forest and forestry industry strategy was agreed to by all participating parties except the Combined Environment Group. Each summer, it would appear, in Tasmania the environment groups launch an area of forestry activity to be campaigned. In previous years, for example, we have had no logging in Jackeys Marsh, no logging in the Douglas Apsley area, no logging in National Estate areas, et cetera. At the end of October the environment movement released its next item on its constantly shifting agenda. It wanted to ban cable logging. When this announcement was made, it was reported in the following manner by the press on 31 October 1990:
Cable logging in Tasmania's forested mountains and hills has caused enormous environmental damage, according to an Australian Conservation Foundation report released yesterday.

The report, whilst it may have been released publicly on 30 October, was in fact one commissioned by the Combined Environment Group as part of its background work for the forest and forest industry strategy. The fact that comments on cable logging from this report were included in the Combined Environment Group's dissenting report means that this report was written well before October, and possibly before September as the forest industries had their comments on the report to the Forest and Forest Industries Council by 13 September.

So the report is one which was commissioned by the Combined Environment Group and paid for by Federal Government funds. I not sure why the report was commissioned in the first place but, more importantly, I am not sure why it was that a Mr Cadman was paid the fee or the commission to write the report. Mr Cadman, for example, had no tertiary qualifications or expertise in forestry, apart from being a resident of Jackeys Marsh and a notable vocal objector to logging in that area. To engage him as a consultant was thus a blatant waste of Federal Government funds.

It would appear that the environmental movement has used the opportunity to fund papers which it would not normally have commissioned, and has provided its mates with some work. I would be interested to know how much Mr Cadman was paid for this report, and perhaps the Minister might be kind enough to respond.

It is not surprising, given Mr Cadman's lack of qualifications in this particular area, that it was a particularly poor report. It is poor for the following key reasons: firstly, there is no clear statement of objectives. The reader is left to draw his own conclusions as to what the study was about. Secondly, there is no clear statement of conclusions. The reader is required to extract conclusions from the section titled `Summary' and that titled `Conclusions'. Indeed, the two sections yield different and differing conclusions. Thirdly, there is no adequate explanation of how environmental impacts are to be defined, how they are to be measured and what constitutes a serious impact. Fourthly, no photographic evidence is given of examples of environmental impact with sufficiently detailed locational information to allow reinspection in the field to assess significance objectively.

In addition, statements are made which show a basic ignorance of the subject. In Mr Cadman's summary his comments can be interpreted to conclude that environmental impacts of cable logging are serious. Impacts considered are those relating to vegetation, soils, streamside integrity and visual integrity. I will refer to just one of these impacts, soils, which is indicative of the scientific standard, or lack thereof, of this report. There is no explanation of what constitutes a serious impact on soils, or on how this is measured objectively. Nor are there photographs with grid coordinates to back up the comment. The comment relates almost exclusively to erosion and distinguishes between road related and coupe erosion.

Out of 33 data sheets, one records road batter erosion as massive. No photograph is provided. One records road related erosion as serious. Again, there is no photograph. One records coupe erosion for part of the coupe as only serious, but, again, no photograph is provided. The remainder of the records reveal both types of erosion of soil as `nil' to `some'.

My conclusion is that there is no evidence of serious soil impact demonstrated in the report. Anyone with some expertise in the soil erosion area talks in terms of tonnes per hectare of soil lost. The more tonnes lost, the greater the impact. Having established the tonnes per hectare, or parts thereof, of soil lost, the significance of the impact then needs to be considered in terms of the impact on such things as plant growth and the possibility of the erosion spots actually growing.

Mr Cadman did not estimate in terms of tonnes per hectare of soil lost, nor did he determine the impact in terms of ongoing erosion and the effect on plant growth. The instance I have referred to is indicative of the tenor of the whole report. Mr Cadman presents no significant evidence to back up his conclusions. These, therefore, remain simply as assertions. Yet Tasmanians have been called upon, on the strength of this report and the media machine of the green movement, to question the environmental impact of cable logging. The vast majority swallowed the misinformation as quickly as one could blink. For the industry that defends it, it is too hard to explain properly in a sentence or so, and so it becomes a matter of taking the industry's word against the conservationist's word, and very few, if any, people actually check the facts. So I provide the facts in this contribution tonight.

Briefly, cable logging or harvesting of timber is not a new process. It has been used in our State of Tasmania for over 100 years in one form or another. Simply, cable harvesting uses a cable to haul timber to a central point rather than using tracked or tyred vehicles to pull the timber. Cable harvesting is an environmentally friendly method of harvesting timber in particularly steep terrain.

Like all forestry operations, cable logging must conform to the forest practices code. The code ensures that all environmental factors are taken into account in the planning and implementation of forest operations and that long term impact on the environment is kept to an acceptable level.

Landscape quality is assessed and harvesting areas are designed such that there is minimal impact on the landscape. This is done by greatly restricting cable harvesting in scenically sensitive areas and controlling it carefully elsewhere.

Vegetation along streams and water courses is protected to ensure that water quality and aquatic ecosystems are preserved. Areas containing rare or endangered plant or animal species are managed to ensure the continued survival of those species. Usually, this means exclusion of harvesting. Fauna populations are protected in strategically placed wildlife habitat strips, streamside reserves and flora reserves which are not harvested.

Because cable harvesting does not involve logging machinery moving about over the harvested area, there is typically insignificant ground disturbance. This means that although the terrain is steep, there is typically insignificant erosion in the related harvesting areas. The reaffores- tation of the harvested area is an important consideration in forest planning, and unless successful regeneration is assured, harvesting will not proceed.

After harvesting has removed all the trees, the area is generally burned and sown with seed distributed from aircraft in the particular coupe. Removal of all trees in the coupe gives all the new seedlings an equal opportunity as they are of the same age. This ensures the best trees will grow because they are not forced to compete for light, water or nutrients with older and taller trees that have been left behind after harvesting. The regenerated area is checked after one year and again after two years to make sure the regeneration has been successful. The regenerated area is therefore acceptable from an aesthetic point of view.
I wish to thank the Senate for the opportunity to inform my fellow senators on cable logging and hopefully to dispel some of the misinformation which has recently been touted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 1 June 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were the Prime Minister, the then Minister for Transport and Communications and the management of the airlines aware as far back as February 1989 that an airline dispute of substantial proportions was planned for later in 1989.
(2) Were they aware that the reason for the dispute was the failure of management to clarify the future of the pilots following 1990 deregulation.

(3) In view of the fact that no action was taken by either the Government or the airline management to prevent the breakdown of services, what fall back positions had the companies and the Government put together between February and August to ensure as little disruption to business and the travelling public as possible for when the dispute inevitably broke.
(4) What severance scale of entitlements would have been due to pilots had they been made redundant by Australian Airlines.
(5) What is the number of pilots currently employed by Australian Airlines and how many were there as at 30 June 1989.
(6) How many pilots currently under contract to Australian Airlines and Ansett are foreign nationals and how many have taken out Australian citizenship since September 1989.

(7) Did the recruitment of any of these foreign nationals involve the speeding up of, or variation of, normal operating procedures available to any other migrant entering the country either permanently or temporarily.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (3) The Australian Federation of Airline Pilots (AFAP) indicated, as early as February 1989, its intention to lodge a claim with the domestic airlines for increased salary levels for pilots. However, the nature and extent of the AFAP's claim was not advised by the Federation until 26 July 1989.

Given that no claim was lodged by the AFAP until 26 July 1989, it was not possible for the Government or the airlines to predict the nature or the extent of the dispute before this time. Upon lodgement of the claim, the airlines notified the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC), and made themselves available for discussions under the Commission's wage fixing system. Following the AFAP's directive of 17 August 1989 to pilots to work between the hours of 9am and 5pm, the Government and the airlines acted promptly to provide essential air services and to also restore full domestic airline services as soon as possible.

On 23 August 1989, the Government announced a number of measures including allowing international carriers to carry domestic passengers and the use of RAAF and VIP aircraft. In addition, the airlines arranged for the lease of additional aircraft and crew from overseas.

(2) The pilots' dispute was based on a claim for a salary increase lodged by the pilots that was outside of the established wages arrangements of the IRC. In lodging its claim with the airlines, the AFAP advised that they would not work within the established wages system, and wished to pursue negotiations outside of the IRC. In contrast, the airlines reiterated their long standing commitment to the established IRC wage fixing system, and sought the claim to be brought before the IRC.

(4) Australian Airlines advises that the pilots' contract of employment with that airline prior to the dispute did not specify a set scale of entitlements for severance pay. Rather, the agreement provided the AFAP with the ability to raise with the airline the matter of severance pay in the case of redundancy at any time during the currency of the agreement.
(5) Australian Airlines currently employs 280 pilots. On 30 June 1989 the airline employed 555 pilots.

(6) The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs approved up to 168 positions under the employer nomination scheme for the permanent entry of foreign pilots between August and the end of December 1989. 104 of these positions were filled. 290 foreign pilots entered Australia as temporary residents after 20 August 1989. I understand that more than 270 of those who entered as temporary residents have already left Australia.

To be eligible for Australian citizenship, a person is normally required to be a permanent resident of Australia for at least two years. Pilots who entered Australia last year will not be eligible to apply for Australian citizenship.

(7) All of the procedures relating to permanent and temporary entry of pilots were normal operating procedures. The treatment accorded the applications for entry was no different for that normally given to applications from companies with urgent needs to fill positions. That is, where applications are submitted in respect of vacancies which need to be filled urgently, additional processing priority is given to those applications above that accorded to other applications for entry to Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many companies are registered outside of Australia in order to avoid taxation.
(2) Is the Federal Government taking any action to stop companies evading Australian taxation laws in this way.
(3) Does the Government have any estimate of the amount of money lost in tax revenue by companies operating outside this country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to compile reliable information because much of the information required is not available in published sources or in tax returns.

(2) Australia's taxation law already contains measures to deal with some aspects of tax evasion through the use of offshore companies. These include provisions to counter practices of related entities that attempt to shift profits away from Australia. The Australian Taxation Office has stepped up audit activity on taxpayers with international transactions.

The Government is taking action to prevent the use of foreign companies to accumulate income offshore to avoid Australian tax. The Government introduced into Parliament on 13 September 1990 comprehensive new measures to tax the foreign source income of Australian residents. These measures will crack down on the use of companies and trusts resident in tax havens to defer Australian tax, while reducing the compliance costs of the foreign tax credit system for companies operating in comparable-tax countries. Additionally, they provide mechanisms by which those Australian-controlled foreign companies engaged in genuine business activities in low-tax jurisdictions can maintain their international competitiveness.

(3) It is very difficult to estimate the extent of tax avoidance and evasion through the use of companies operating outside Australia to accumulate income offshore free of Australian tax. The estimate cannot be made from information furnished in tax returns because companies not resident in Australia are required to lodge tax returns only if they derive Australian-source income.

The published annual reports of Australian companies detail the contribution to accounting profits of subsidiaries incorporated outside Australia. However, accounting profits are not always equivalent to taxable income. Because of this, the published reports are very often not sufficient to establish a reliable overall estimate of the amount of taxable income derived outside Australia by all those offshore entities whose ultimate beneficial owners are Australian resident.
I note that the new taxation of foreign source income measures are expected to raise directly $60m-$70m in a full year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 October:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Minister criticised the Fijian Government for threatening punitive action against academics at the University of the South Pacific in September 1990.

(2) Is the Australian Government aware of the fact that an academic at the University of Wollongong is being intimidated by the University authorities over research work he wishes to conduct in the Philippines; if so, does it intend to raise the matter with the relevant authorities at the University.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Reports of the threat did, however, lead me to inquire into the position of academic staff at the University of the South Pacific, which is a regional, multi-national institution. The situation is that USP rules require that a member of the academic staff elected or appointed to an official position in any political party shall be deemed to have resigned from the date of election or appointment. The rules also require that Heads of Schools and similar senior academic staff should refrain from public political activities. The University Council has taken the view that these rules are reasonable in a regional body and that they do not unfairly restrict the freedom of University staff to engage in political activity. I am satisfied that the existing rules do not prejudice the integrity of the USP or cut across generally accepted standards of academic freedom, although I would deplore it if they were used, or elaborated, for this purpose.

(2) I believe that the instance referred to by Senator Vallentine involves an academic in the Department of History and Politics at the University of Wollongong who has sought study leave of a year's duration for 1991 in which to conduct research in the Philippines. I have been informed by the University authorities that the initial application for study leave was referred back to the applicant on the grounds that it was not in accordance with standard University rules and procedures. For instance, the University generally restricts periods of study leave to six months rather than one year. The applicant was therefore requested to resubmit his application and assured that it would be ``assessed by the same rules that apply to all staff.'' Contact with the University does not indicate that the academic concerned has been in any way intimidated by University authorities.

Greater use of the civil infrastructure and industry; and
Greater use of Reserve forces.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 16 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of recent reported cases of women dying in childbirth and widespread malnutrition on Bougainville because the Papua New Guinea Government blockade is preventing all foodstuffs and medical supplies from reaching the island.
(2) What explanation can the Minister provide for the Australian Government's stated position that aid to Bougainville would be viewed as illegal.

(3) Does the Australian Government agree with a recent Papua New Guinea Government intelligence report which argues that depriving the residents of Bougainville of all supplies was the most effective way of eroding support for the self determination movement on the island.

(4) What view does the Australian Government hold in relation to the recent statement from the Catholic Bishops of Papua New Guinea that, at the very least, the International Red Cross should be admitted onto Bougainville as a humanitarian measure.
(5) Will the Australian Government encourage the Papua New Guinea Government to invite the International Red Cross to send representatives onto Bougainville.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government is aware of reports that some pregnant women have died in childbirth because of the lack of surgical facilities since the closure of Arawa hospital.

(2) The Australian Government's position is that unilateral action to send supplies into Bougainville in breach of the PNG Note to Mariners, would contravene PNG law, and as such could not be condoned by the Government. Any shipment of medical supplies, food or other goods to Bougainville which has the endorsement of the PNG Government, would be welcomed by the Australian Government.
(3) The matter is an internal affair for Papua New Guinea.
(4 &5) The PNG Prime Minister recently announced approval in principle for the Red Cross to travel to Bougainville in the interests of alleviating unnecessary suffering.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What electorate for the House of Representatives had the largest enrolment on the most recent figures, and which electorate had the smallest enrolment, excluding Tasmanian electorates.
(2) What were the largest and smallest enrolments at the corresponding time in 1982, excluding Tasmania.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The most recent electoral enrolment figures are those at 31 October 1990. The largest enrolment figure is for the Division of McPherson (Qld) with 89783.
The smallest enrolment figure is that for the Division of Wentworth (NSW) with 64513.
(2) For the corresponding period in 1982, the figures for October that year showed the largest electoral enrolment was for the Division of Fisher (Qld) with 96068.
The smallest enrolment figure was for the Northern Territory (56941) but among the mainland States, the Division of Curtin (WA) had the smallest enrolment figure with 61314.
